content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've played RimWorld for quite a while before the Steam release, but I'll try to keep my remarks focused on the Alpha 14 version.Scenarios are interesting. They offer a fresh experience to someone like me who has played and tested the game to death. They allow you to change the rules of the game and create a unique story.I've played with mods in RimWorld before, but having Workshop support at launch has meant that it's even easier for modders to get their mods in the hands of people. Of course, for modders there is a downside - it's more difficult than ever to get visibility for a mod unless it's advertised elsewhere or it reaches a certain threshold of subscribers and gets into a collection.But I digress. The gameplay itself is similar to previous versions, but a few adjustments have been made. For example, wild animals and visitors trapped within walls will now attempt to dig their way out and leave instead of standing around until starvation and insanity set in. An AI which doesn't react to exploitative gameplay spoils my immersion. So this gets a thumbs up from me.Another small but significant change - roofing is now something which must be constructed, rather than instantly appearing as soon as a room is completed. If I get too ambitious building shacks for colonists, some of them will have walls but nothing above them to keep out the elements.The insect infestations which were introduced in Alpha 13 now occur in a narrower range of conditions. Given that they're intended as a consequence for digging deeply and greedily into the mountains, this means you need only fear an infestation if you've actually mined into the mountain rather than picking at the visible veins.Map conditions can now be permanent as part of the scenario system. If you've ever wondered how you might survive on a planet where electronic devices don't work because of constant solar flare activity, now's your chance. Or perhaps you prefer the eternal night, in which case a permanent Eclipse is right up your street.You can now play as a tribe, rather than a group of crashed survivors. There's a bit of a challenge to be had, initially surviving without all the technological advantages that industrial-age colonists have. Indeed, your tribe learns those secrets at a slower rate - the more advanced the technology, the longer it takes for it to be researched. Great for long-term playthroughs.Tribes do have one ace up their sleeve - they start with the knowledge required to make a long-term food preserve called pemmican. This is a great way of using up meat which would otherwise go bad in warm temperatures.The gun turrets which were a staple of previous alphas now need to be researched. This means that in the early stages of a game, you need to stave off raids with deadfall traps and whatever weapons you can make, buy or loot. It definitely gives you an incentive to do research.It seems that there are a few minor issues with Alpha 14 which will be fixed in a later iteration. For example, there's no real benefit to mining into a mountain if you want to escape the outdoor heat.Overall, I would say that this has been the best update yet, and I can't wait to see what else Tynan and Ludeon Studios are cooking up.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								Like Prison Architect (in art style) meets Dwarf Fortress, but without as much complexity or depth (literal and figurative).Whereas in Dwarf Fortress the UI is a mess and you can dig through many layers and do many many things, Rimworld seemingly decided to start with the bare-bones of making a user-friendly UI and build up from there. The game is in Alpha 14 at the time of writing this but it feels pretty complete in the early-game. There is plenty to do and build for long enough to keep you coming back for days, but as you advance your colony you may realize the game slows down a bit as it goes on. This is likely just a product of Alpha-ness that will be addressed in future updates though, I can't imagine the developer doesn't have lots of plans.That said, when you start installing Mods and Mod-packs is when this game *really* shines. Between the "Hardcore SK" mod pack, "Mega MOD Pack", or many others, the game turns from a bare-bones almost-Dwarf Fortress into a game truly capable of standing up in its' own right.The mod community for this game is huge and adds a lot to this type of game; From combat "realism" overhauls, to new structures/production/technology trees, to even new character traits, mods turn this game up to 11.

								I don't normally write reviews but this game is one of my favourites of all time, and I know it just came out on steam so a lot of steam users will not know anything about it.This game is kind of like dwarf fortress lite, it is simpler and better looking than DF, but has similar gameplay concepts. The main thing that makes this game great is that it has a very simple, streamlined and comprehensive modding system. This means that there are hundreds of excellent mods available so you can get the gameplay you like customised for yourself. I imagine it will take a while before all the mods make it onto the workshop, especially given that they probably have to be updated for the newest version. But you can check out what is available on the forum: https://ludeon.com/forums/index.php?board=15.0If you like squad based tactical games, survival games or resource management strategy games this one is worth a look. If you are turned off by 2d graphics then this is probably not for you.Ignore my steam hours played stat, I have played thousands of hours of this but I uses a heavily modded directory which I will probably never let the steam update system get near. Even just starting the game for 5 minutes in steam overwrote my mod config file. Until steam implements the ability to roll back updates so that you can keep playing your modded version for a while after a patch comes out, I would recommend copying the directory out of steam if you are using a lot of mods.

								Rimworld is currently one of my favourite games to date, and I've been playing it for 2 years before it launched on steam. I can only say; GET IT. You can easily sink hours upon hours into Rimworld. You get attached to your colonist. You share their joy, feel their pain and mourn when they die. Early Access Review
								Here's some things you can do in RimWorld. Amputate someone's limbs and replace them with prosthetic Tame anything from elephants to wild boars to defend you and carry supplies Watch your settlers interact and form relationships, maybe even have affairs Transplant organs, and harvest them from unlucky prisoners Cook luxury meals from space insects and potatos Fight robo-centipedes Craft anything from uranium swords to charge rifles Hunt explosive "Boomalope" Have base burnt down by said creature Capture raiders as prisoners and persuade them to join your colony Steal from trade caravansEDIT: NEW UPDATE! The game's even better! There's a great tutorial for new players, and a drug system. Now I would recommend the game more than ever. And, 140 hours later, I'm still playing...

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								Insane fun game, the amount of stories what can happen to your colony/tribe is mind blowing with all the attention to the details.Example of one of my stories:Had a guy nicknamed Amigo, was a pyromaniac. That trait makes him randomly ignite stuff and he also refuses to extinguish fire. So one day he decides to freaking burn my whole farm and forest. A huge fire takes place which then additionally also burned half of my main house as it was made out of wood. Everyone helped to take ot the fire except that piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ofc. Luckily before everything got too late it started raining which safed my colony.Some months later he tried to flirt with the married woman of my best colonist, she turned him down. He went full retard and wanted to burn something down - knowing the outcome I ordered my bodyguard to knock him down with a club. The fight made him mad so I tied him up and put him in his room. After a few days he was healed and could move again (my bodyguard really messed him up).I really thought that I have control about Amigo now back, but then that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ goes mad again and ♥♥♥♥ing ignites his own room - while he was imprisioned there (must be really desperate for women, as he tried it with every female he could find), In the proces Merlen the bodyguard went off to stop the chaos, in the heat of battle (literally heat) he knocked him down again.Beeing mad at him I had no other choice than to execute him this time. So Merlen went with him into his repaired room and finished of his friend. After that drama he got burried and things started to went back to normal -1 worker.Sadly two days later all the other coloniest got♥♥♥♥♥♥♥by raiders (ironically in that raider group Amigos brother was taking part of it too). Fun fact Merlen was originally from that faction too, but I captured him (while his mate got killed in the attack on the colony) and recruited him for my cause.Happy End.Don't get fooled by the "Early Access" tag - this game is fully functional and nearly bugfree.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								I purchased RimWorld roughly a year ago during the somewhat early stages of its development. And since then I have sunk hundreds (if not thousands) of hours into it before it was finally brought onto Steam. I did not come from a background of Dwarf Fortress of Prison Architect, nor did I believe that I would be a fan of the methodical and careful harvesting, construction and management that RimWorld's gameplay prominently features. I bought into RimWorld because I saw my favorite streamer play it, and it seemed different than the masses of shooters and fighting games that I had invested so much time into.When I first booted up RimWorld, I sat down with a glass of ice water and familiarized myself with its core gameplay mechanics. Each of your villagers is unique, with varying degrees of aptitude in everything from mining to creating artistic masterpieces. Your job as the player is to assign tasks that these villagers will complete based on their intelligent AI system; it is critical that you carefully manage what tasks are prioritized by which villager in order to ensure that your villagers are constantly working to build and improve your colony. However this is balanced by a Mood system that requires that you also manage your villager's health and recreational levels. That's the basic rundown of the system but I could go on for hours and hours and hours about the intricacies of the game. What's important is that you won't find yourself confused by how the game works at all.By the time I was wrapping up my first session of RimWorld, I reached over to take a drink from my glass of cold water and realized that all the ice had melted and it was lukewarm. Somehow, nine hours had passed. I was hooked. When a mad boar gored a good man to death, I wept. While my men and women fought with raider scum, I shouted with rage and frustration. And when even in the midst of surviving in a harsh and unforgiving new world, my survivors still found time to find love, I celebrated. There is something beautiful about RimWorld's complex (yet simple) gameplay. It manages to reach out and grab you, to really make you feel invested in the tiny pixels that mill about on your computer screen. It's very appropriate that the game's AI systems are labeled as storytellers, because RimWorld tells a story - your story. How it develops and ends is entirely up to you, and that's what makes RimWorld so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed fun. All you need is a playlist of your favorite music and a nice glass of your favorite refreshment and you're ready to create a beautiful new world.Buy this game. If you have even the slightest interest in base building or city building simulations, or have any sort of history in games of those genres you will enjoy RimWorld thoroughly. It's also incredible how amazing RimWorld's developers are at building and expanding upon the game. These are people who refused to release the game because they felt like the game "needed more features and depth," though I can say with certainty that at the time it had plenty of both. These devs are committed to making this game an amazing one, and I'd recommend you get behind it. Also boomrat infestation ♥♥♥♥ed my best colony, please send help. There's fire everywhere and my people are dying out I'm gonna go insa-

content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								i will now recount a very tragic love storyour colony was thriving and we had just recruited a new member of our society, a woman which i named dracula. in her bio it said that she had a lover, james living far away somewhere. later i recieved a message that read that james himself was joining our colony. he must have longed for his lover dracula for some time and had finally decided to join her and be with her after all this time. truly a display of true love. after alot of planning and preparation james finally had the guts to propose to her but she coldheartedly rejected james and ended the relationship. after the soulcrushing rejection james lost his mind and went of a very sad wander to reflect over his life. he wandered for an entire night and when he came back she was waiting for him.....when he arrived she instatly insulted him and ofc he insulted back, that started an argument and that spiraled into a massive fist fight in which with one strong blow dracula murdered james, shattering his spine. then to avoid suspicion she hastily burried his shatterd body in a nearby open grave.after we reburried him in a sarcophagus as he deserved, what was he remembered for? his sad psycological breakdown..that poor sod may you rest in peace james this game is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've played RimWorld for the last 2 and a half years on and off. Through the whole time Tynan put a lot of work and effort into the game. It has grown from a litlle towerdefense game to a full fleteched simulation game,  which you can slowly begin to  compare to the big dog DwarfFortress. It's still not as complex as DF (but which game is?) and it maybe never will, but it's the closest thing you get. Love this game, the community is great, and you can mod the sh*t out of it. If DF just frustrates you, but you still got that hardcore simultation game itch you wanna scratch, BUY IT!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is a great game. It says early access, but I have never encountered any bugs that I can recall. There are regular updates and improvements. It has Steam integration.The developer seems to be absolutely invested in improving and expanding an already great game. You can run it on a non-supercomputer (see: laptop) just fine. One impression you may get from it, is that it's one of those hard games that keeps coming at you until it destroys you. This is not the case at all. You set the difficulty in the begining. You can set it to a hard level, but I like to set it on "base building mode", which is just the second hardest difficulty level. It provides some challenge, but allows you to build up your community.I'll tell you one thing that happened to me. The mood of your colonists is important. I had one guy that was very talented but a bit neurotic, and one day he went nuts. Unfortunately he went nuts homocidal style, and started attacking his fellow colonists. Of course the colonists returned fire and killed him. Unfortunately, he had bonded as the main handler for a pair of fully grown bears. They didn't like when he was attacked; like not at all. You can imagine the bloodbath that ensued.The potential for unpredictability and unforseen consequences in this game is really high. It's an indie title that I cannot recommend enough. If it sounds like it's up your alley, grab it (on sale or not).

A+++++++++

content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								Very simple, One of the best stragety, survival base-building games out there. Worth every penny. - More Details:                        I've been playing this game for a while now, even before the (Steam) release. And the impressions on this game were outstanding. There's so much you can do, manage and think or act fast for the safety of your colony, in this case it depends on the type storyteller you choose from/game-mode. -Challenges:                  The game offers three types of storytellers, each with a different perspective. Either you are a hardcore player or peaceful/dislike challenges. The game also have season, these are; Spring, Summer, Fall and Winter. Keep in mind tempetures are very important for farming. Of course, all this depends on how you play or customize your gameplay, endless possibilities to start from.-Colonist:              Each colonist have their own traits, likes, dislikes, relationships, friendships, opinions, gay, straigh, lessbian, cold blooded, nudist, night owls etc... you name it. Each, trait will have an impact against others as in real life of course. However, those personalities will affect and cause rage and fights and even lead to serious injuries. If not dealt with as best as possible for the good of your colonists/happiness.-Biomes:              A variety of biomes are offer to play on. Each one of them provides with differents kind of wild life as well temperature and natural resource to use at your avantage. - Research and Craft:                               Research is very important to craft great gear, weapons and many useful utilities to enforce your colony and their survival.--------------------------------------TO BE UNCONTINUED-------------------------------------   There is more than you can think of.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								Ok so I have been playing this game since August of 2015 (pre-steam release) and I'd say I put about 400+ hours into the game. I feel I can comfotable give a decent review. From me, this game receives a  9.2/10 . This game only gets better with its constant stream of updates. Some say it feels unfinished but in my opinion this could ship as a finished game now. Pros   High  replayability. Fun combat mechanics. Open building system with tech trees (Building is similar to Prison Achritect). Indepth health system. Many different play styles. Lots of mods available. Cons  Some bugs. Can be hard to start off / mildly steep learning curve. No solid end-game.  PLEASE KEEP IN MIND RIMWORLD RECEIVES REGULAR UPDATES AND IS IN EARLY ACCESS!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								I would estimate the time I have put into Rimworld to be something along the lines of several hundreds of hours. To me, Rimworld is a game one can never get tired of. It becomes great fun, especially in later stages as you progress and develop your colonies, both internal and external conflicts will arise and with the latest updates there are a plethora of possibilities present. You tailor a scenario to your own liking, which means you can choose how you want to start, what traits your characters start with, what clothing, how old they are, and much much more.In short it seems like a watered down Dwarf Fortress, but it still remains a damn good game to this day.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								I very highly recommend this game!It's a truly unique game, and very well designed. It can be a little tough starting out, but it's not dwarf fortress. The mechanics are simple, but the game has so many features and interactions between them that there's a lot of depth. The fact that your colonists are mostly automated lets you sit back and make decisions rather than micro-managing.The randomized events, map generation, and different biomes give the game a lot of replayability. I actually have about 100 hours more than steam says, because I had the game before it was on steam.Make sure to look into mods after you've learned the game! This game has amazing mod support, and there are dozens, maybe hundreds of good quality mods out there. Steam workshop makes it really easy to search and find them too.

content:

Early Access Review
								I don't really go for these survival sim type games, but on recommendation from a friend I picked this up yesterday.  Do I recommend it YES, WHOLE HEARTEDLY YES!!  Rather than a review (I'm terrible at reviewing stuff) let me give you a rough synopsis of my current colony.We crash land on a planet, slowly beginning to get our bearings and some shelter, storage and garden built.  All of a sudden we notice a Timber Wolf nearby, is it friendly or hostile?  Our resident Hunter would rather not take a chance, so breaks out his rifle and fires a number  of times.  Out of 6 shots, 2 hit their mark, but sadly all this seems to do is♥♥♥♥♥♥the wolf off, who comes charging at our Hunter, he fumbles reloading and ends up having to take off at speed to try and avoid getting eaten,  obiviously the Wolf is faster than our Hunter so he's constantly being nipped at the heals.ANOTHER ALERT!!A Squirrel has gone nuts and is attacking one of the other colonists, chasing her down until she collapses from her wounds far from base.  She needs rescuing, so I send out my final colonist to bring her home.  In the mean time our Hunter is looking a lot worse for wear and is slowly making his way back to base with wolf in tow.  He just makes it inside in time.  Wolf starts banging at the door trying to get in.Cut to the other 2 colonists, they're now helping each other back to base, after the Squirrel attack, unaware there is a Timber Wolf trying to get in.Oh no, he's seen them, just before they get through the door to safety he pounces, killing one and severely injuring the other.  Wolf passes out due to his injuries from the Hunter.Hunter heres the commotion die down and begins to head towards the door, completely unaware his pet cat, enraged by the smell of blood, attacks him and leaves him immobile on the floor.So now I have 2 immobile survivors and absolutely nothing I can do, but wait for the infections to set in and kill them.Just when I had given up all hope, a native comes to our area to join our happy little colony, he carries the injured to their beds, treats their wounds and feeds them, before going to bed himself.and that my friends is where I have left this story.  I can't wait to see what happens next.What will your story be?

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								As you can probably tell, I've put a few hours into this game.This is one of those games where you'll lose a day in, an entire day. You'll wake up in the morn, open it up, and the next thing you know, your colony is being assaulted by exploding rats and it's 7am the next day. Not saying that happened to me, but still.It has a lot of mods, some that are really good, some that are necessary, some that are "Well, that's a cool idea, but I don't need it". There's also a series of Lovecraft mods that allow you to be assaulted by Eldritch Abominations or make your own cult. Neato.The game has problems in a few areas, but what game doesn't have problems? The most recent patch of A16 nerfed drugs a bit too much to be used, but can still be sold by the dump truck load easily. Never used drugs with my colonists, so whatever.The game doesn't have multiplayer and honestly, it doesn't really need it or I can't see how it would be implimented anyways. Multiplayer is something that should honestly be added last, after everything else the dev Tynan adds.Anyways, enough rambling, back in I dive.TL;DRGame is gr8. 10/10 Would make Human Leather Cowboy Hats and Dusters again.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								I would estimate the time I have put into Rimworld to be something along the lines of several hundreds of hours. To me, Rimworld is a game one can never get tired of. It becomes great fun, especially in later stages as you progress and develop your colonies, both internal and external conflicts will arise and with the latest updates there are a plethora of possibilities present. You tailor a scenario to your own liking, which means you can choose how you want to start, what traits your characters start with, what clothing, how old they are, and much much more.In short it seems like a watered down Dwarf Fortress, but it still remains a damn good game to this day.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								I very highly recommend this game!It's a truly unique game, and very well designed. It can be a little tough starting out, but it's not dwarf fortress. The mechanics are simple, but the game has so many features and interactions between them that there's a lot of depth. The fact that your colonists are mostly automated lets you sit back and make decisions rather than micro-managing.The randomized events, map generation, and different biomes give the game a lot of replayability. I actually have about 100 hours more than steam says, because I had the game before it was on steam.Make sure to look into mods after you've learned the game! This game has amazing mod support, and there are dozens, maybe hundreds of good quality mods out there. Steam workshop makes it really easy to search and find them too.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								Very simple, One of the best stragety, survival base-building games out there. Worth every penny. - More Details:                        I've been playing this game for a while now, even before the (Steam) release. And the impressions on this game were outstanding. There's so much you can do, manage and think or act fast for the safety of your colony, in this case it depends on the type storyteller you choose from/game-mode. -Challenges:                  The game offers three types of storytellers, each with a different perspective. Either you are a hardcore player or peaceful/dislike challenges. The game also have season, these are; Spring, Summer, Fall and Winter. Keep in mind tempetures are very important for farming. Of course, all this depends on how you play or customize your gameplay, endless possibilities to start from.-Colonist:              Each colonist have their own traits, likes, dislikes, relationships, friendships, opinions, gay, straigh, lessbian, cold blooded, nudist, night owls etc... you name it. Each, trait will have an impact against others as in real life of course. However, those personalities will affect and cause rage and fights and even lead to serious injuries. If not dealt with as best as possible for the good of your colonists/happiness.-Biomes:              A variety of biomes are offer to play on. Each one of them provides with differents kind of wild life as well temperature and natural resource to use at your avantage. - Research and Craft:                               Research is very important to craft great gear, weapons and many useful utilities to enforce your colony and their survival.--------------------------------------TO BE UNCONTINUED-------------------------------------   There is more than you can think of.

Early Access Review
								Incredible. That is how I would describe this game if only permitted one word. The gameplay, while not groundbreaking, is unique to each playthrough and provides great stories of heroism, comradery, and the inevitable downfall of your colony. The modding community for this game is amazing, considering the relatively short time since it's availability. The game is still in the alpha faze yet provides more entertainment than most major releases have been able to. I recommend this game to anyone that enjoys sandbox gameplay with little or no goals other than prosperity. Truly one of the better games on Steam.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								Been playing the game since soon after it was released, and I've kept coming back to it.Rimworld is a 2D, top-down, science-fiction, story-driven colony basebuilding game. If you've played Dwarf Fortress, you'll find it pretty easy to pick up. If not, your colonists are probably going to get shot, frozen, eaten, burned, and so on before you get the hang of it, but its tutorial system is quite clever and generally makes sure you're on the right track.The game takes place 3500 years in the future, where humans have colonized the stars and so on. Because there is no faster-than-light travel in the game, some civilizations have regressed without contact with other civilizations. You crash-land on a world on the edge of colonized space and are given three survivors, two guns between them, and a few supplies that didn't burn up in the atmosphere. On the rimworld with you are indigenous pre-agricultural tribes, medieval feudal kingdoms, modern city-states, post-scarcity transhuman roboticist spacers, and any number of pirates trying to take your♥♥♥♥♥♥ and you have to survive by trading with, kidnapping, or slaughtering them as you try not to die of ♥♥♥♥ing malaria or hypothermia or get eaten by wolves.It's pretty fun, well worth the $30.

Early Access Review
								Rimworld is a mix between dwarf fortress, banished, prison architect and kings of dragon's pass. Strangely enough, I never got into one of those games, but this one is very addictive.Creating your colony from scratch, watching all the different characters interact is fun indeed, even when everything goes wrong. And it will go wrong sooner or later. Stories are created this way and you really feel invested in them.Replayability is through the roof and a lot of mods enhance it even further. Highly recommended and it's even early access!

content:
Posted: July 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								Unbelievably addictive and fun.In many ways, it resembles the ultimate simulation game that I've always wanted, a realistic simulation of surviving in a different world. Every aspect of living is simulated, Temeperature Jungles settlements need aircons to prevent heatstroke, iceworlds need heating. And those two need electricity, so if a solar flare knocks out your generators, you are in trouble, neccessatting good insulation and wood supply to outlast the solar flare.Most food will spoil in a few days, so construct a cooler to freeze a room and store your food there (this can be easily automated)! But freezers like in real life merely transfer the heat to another room. So this freezer needs vents connecting outside to prevent overheating the other rooms! This of course is unneccesary if your biome is freezing yearround, just build it outside to benefit from the environment.Food You can farm, keep animal husbandry, or hunt. Its possible to survive on just one source, but meat+veggies gives mood bonuses. If a wave of toxic fallout comes, or the outside terrain is too inhospitable, then you may need indoor farming with hydroponic farms and sun lamps. Cannibalism is always available for the desperate, but that gives severe penalities to mood (unless they have the cannibal trait, which gives a huge boost instead!).Mental stateYour colonists/pawns do have emotions, they may breakdown in stages if their mood is too low, making mood an extremely important part of the game. Brew beer, make sure the colony is tidy and clean without corpses, decorate with art, wear good clothing, etc etc.HealthYour colonists have detailed health stats, from fingers to toes to each major organ, they can all be damaged in combat. A good doctor can treat them, but sometimes wounds are so severe lungs, legs, eyes can be destroyed, so now you should either buy an expensive organ from traders,  or capture a prisoner and harvest their organs instead! (This gives a mood penalty unless the pawns have the psycopath traits)Depending on the biome, they can get a variety of infectious diseases, malaria to flu to sleeping sickness, then they are bedridden for a long time, you'd have to prepare for this eventuality if you are living in a jungle.CombatCombat is tactically simple but strategically deep, the positioning of your base, preconstructed defenses and traps, weapons and armor, will determine the result long before it begins. Enemies are affected by the same stats as your own pawns, so playing in iceworld biome with -90c temperature outside during winter means your enemies will just freeze to death while they attempt to bash down your doors!ConstructionYou can build your base outdoors or inside mountains, the first is faster but the latter is safer (can't have droppods penetrating mountanis), Strategically design it for work efficiency, thermal insulation, and defensive capabilities. Your pawns don't like sharing bedrooms or being disturbed in their sleep, organically pushing you to make seperate bedrooms with a hallway connecting them.PawnsEvery colonist is different, with different personality traits, different skills, different prohibitions, different health conditions, they really come alive and ensures you care (or hate) each individual pawn. You can assign the types of tasks they can work on and they automatically do so. But they also need play, need food (and a table to eat), and may be distracted. You merely guide them, not dictate them, which makes them more alive than the sims in my opinion. In combat though you can control them 100%, which prevents frustration in these critical momements, with just enough micromanagement to feel fun but not tedious.See the multitude of dimensions a player has to consider? This means there is always something on your mind, always something you can do better, driving you to play for hours and hours, I bought this game without much expectation (didn't like prison simulator), but it has proven incredibly addictive.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 2
Early Access Review
								Day 1: Three soldiers two being AWOL brothers Pvt. Loco and Sgt. Jenson and supervised by a super neurotic general “The Spear” that tends to babble concerning things, his squad will follow him unconditionally though. After landing on a strange planet all three-set out upon to find a good place to lay low for the night as temperatures reached to around -4 degrees. The three stumbled upon a derelict building with no structural damage so they built a door and bedded down for their first time in this unknown place.Day 2: After waking from their cramped place Jenson walked outside and in the morning sunlight now noticed the huge bay area was completely walled in on every side, leaving just a small opening leaving little area for an ambush.  The rest of the day was spent building a central outpost building inside the cove.Day 3: The Spear awoke hearing a far-off sound of gunfire. He stumbled through the darkness of the new home they had built outside where he sat and listened…… two minutes go by and all seemed well, Spear hadn’t heard anything but had a very uneasy feeling, a shot rang out and smashed into the wood wall next to Spear he without hesitation ,due to his Veteran background, wheeled to his left and shot his rifle through the darkness, a yell rang out and he knew he had hit his mark, at this moment Jenson and Loco were out the door. With the spears eyes finally adjusted he noticed that they still weren’t alone. Hiding behind the sandbag fort they had built that day Spear began to tell Jenson and Loco that he had seen two figures in the darkness. Loco without hesitation leaped over the sandbags and went off into the darkness. Jenson knew Loco had always bore a bloodlust ever since he was an orphan as a child and both were forced into gang life. Jenson slaughtered a 17-year-old boy and 23-year-old girl. They were attempting to flee as Loco got both and stabbed each over 12 times. His bloodlust was filled and he went to bed happy even with the bruises he sustained.Day 12: The three have been through hell and have been joined by a follower by the name of Greer. The fort had sustained multiple raids that yielded one prisoner, Claudia, and had raised considerable defenses. It was this day that the end became a real reality. Jenson ran into Spears room to which he stumbled upon a babbling crazed Spear. He was having one of his flashbacks from the Great war of 5487, these could go on for hours even up to days. A raid was imminent and the spear had been hoarding ammo for the two guns left for the fort. This left no other choice but for Loco, Greer, and Jenson to pick up what melee weapons they had left and set up a defensive position. Raiders outnumbered our combatants 4/3 and our first casualty was Greer. He sustained a shot to the head and died nearly instantly. Loco went into another of his rages and killed two of the raiders before succumbing to his injuries and going down. Jenson also knocked one out with a club causing the last raider to run away. It was this moment Spear ran out the door and one shot rang out through the cove. He had killed the fleeing raider. Jenson meanwhile took Loco to his bed and with closer examination noticed Loco had 3 fingers missing and was a deep gash in his thigh. Jenson tried his best for hours but Loco eventually died of blood loss. Overwhelmed Jenson took out his pistol and began to look for Spear intent on ending his life for getting them into this situation. As Jenson broke into Spears room he was no match Spear unleashed a shot right though Jenson’s shoulder. Spear with the hate of betrayal in his eyes shot once more into Jenson’s chest killing him. Spear began a downward spiral from this point on. Survivals guilt set in and he became depressed. Day 14: Now out of food Spear has begun to starve and being too depressed to gather food was rapidly wasting away. Claudia’s screams from the prison began to grow louder and louder as the hunger pains began to grow worse. As Spear began to bury the bodies left outside he notice it was starting to snow. Temperatures had reached -23 degrees and The Spear knew Claudia must have been freezing and starving, so he grabbed a basket of berries to bring to her, but as he walked by one of the bodies he noticed it was his son who had joined the pirate nation nearby. Spear had planned to leave that night and travel to another village, but he finally snapped. He walked to the storage closet where he took out the IED that he got scavenging after a raid and strapped it under his vest. As Spear opened the dark grisly prison door his life flashed before him. Claudia with little energy she had lunged at the spear as he grabbed her and pushed her into the cell closing the door behind them. Spear shouted “ALLAH AKBAH lol jk” and detonated destroying both of their bodies leaving nothing left of the stone cell just the door. The three Vets had a total of 16 confirmed kills, and were all awarded metal of honors post-Humorously Please get this game it’s one of the best, after putting hundreds of hours into Dwarf Fortress and I can say that this game can one day be as ambiguous as Dwarf fortress and I hope to put hundreds of hours onto this game.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								After 11 hours of playtime, planning to have thousands this, yet still Early Access Game, is extremely fun. I looked at the game and frowned upon it, but pushed my self to buy it and test it out. I do NOT regret it, I've had so much fun already. The game can be quite challening at times, especially on the higher dificulites, but it's all a learning progress. The funniest, most chaotic moment I've had on this game so for would be during a storm and raid at the same time. I had 4 colonists and a medium sized colony, all buildings very close to each other. Lighting strikes 1 building and fire breaks out everywhere. A lamp also explodes catching crops and another building on fire, then a raid!!! 4 raiders are coming in from 2 different sides and my base is burning down, my AI is scrambling everywhere, when boom, lightning hits again., and we have more fire spreading. We manage to kill 2 of the raiders, and damage a 3rd pretty bad, whom later bleeds out, while the 4th raider gives up and leaves, By this point almost everything is gone, and everyone is bleeding and we have 1 without eyes..... He dies of infection very quickly, a second gets a major infection in his torso from gun shots, another has infection in her legs and the last bleeds out. We have no food, no shelter, and only about 2 things of medicine left, sadly we all died. ): I reccomend this game for a blast!!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 8
Early Access Review
								Ah Lovecraft mods. No matter what game they managed to slither into they always makes for interesting stories. This is one such story.The planet I ended up with was a desert with a large number of mountains and a huge ♥♥♥♥ing ocean. So I go the rich explorer and give myself a little boost in wood and cloth. I crash land into a tundra. There are pockets of rabbits and squirrels, along with some Elephants. So I build a little♥♥♥♥♥♥shack and get to work building into a nearby mountain. And after a few days my colonist (Wendy) suddenly runs off. I see her go towards this spooky lookin' monolith. She stands there for a second and then goes back to her room. She then makes an Occult Grimoir and takes a huge mood debuff. This is where things take a fun turn. I build into another mountain and mine out a giant church and occult research room. I get it all floored and lighted up and set to work. While researching weird symbols Wendy turns into a Cultist. Nice. She then names her cult the Esoteric Order of Dagon...fitting. I craft her up some robes and a Cthulhu mask. I then end up making an altar and sacrificing some rabbits for power. Then I get the message, two people join me in obsession of joining my cult... alrighty. I craft them up some robes and get them some beds in already mined out rooms.Now we skip to season later. I've held off countless raids from the local tribes and even some Deep Ones. Wendy is now head cultist and everyone has a good life. My mountain base is now a fortress equipped with untold eldritch horrors trapped within the stone. I am now fairly well equipped with some guns and a many melee weapons. My colony is now 7 strong and has no signs of stopping. Sermons are held for Great Cthulhu and father Dagon. But life is kinda boring as while the Lovecraft storyteller can be brutal it doesn't really give you a ton of events to work with. So I gather my cultists find a nearby coastal village. So I caravan up and gather my most loyal followers and set to work. We arrive to what can only be described as a shanty town. I draw a rune and wait. Now when the first thing you research on, on the forbidden research table is figuring out what all those ♥♥♥♥ing symbols are. And when done researching you can then make a rune that attracts Deep Ones. They will defend the rune with their life until they are all dead. The towns people put up a fairly good fight and even managed to take down a Greater Deep One. But that was all for naught as they were then slaughtered by the eldritch tide. Mopping up the Deep Ones was easy for me as Harpoon-guns work wonders against them. I then take all the coastal towns♥♥♥♥♥♥and ♥♥♥♥ back off to my colony. A great first raid, and there were still so many more to come. And while raiding coastal towns was fun for a little bit I got bored, but it was mostly because I killed all the coastal towns in my area. But something did come my way as one of the local tribes tried raiding me again, but this time...with an army. My guard of Deep Ones could only hold off the tide for so long before they got overwhelmed. My turrets did most of the killing, along with the more...unstable part of my colony. But they did♥♥♥♥♥♥me off, they killed the co-head cultist and Wendy's lover. Wendy fell into a deep depression and I had to straitjacket her so she wouldn't go off the rails and murder people. This lasted for some time, but Wendy did eventually get out of her stopper and started leading sermons and daily sacrifices once more. But she was out for revenge and as it turns out the tribe responsible for killing Wendy's lover was also the biggest tribe in the world. And thus began the war. It was easy at first as my tide of Deep Ones did most of the work for me, but the farther I pushed into their territory the harder the raids would get...and the wounded count would also get higher. Lucky was I that my underground farms has reaped a bountiful harvest this season and I had a plenty herbal medicine in stock. It did get tricky when a plague of insanity swept through my lands and rendered most of my colony null. It wasn't until Wendy herself died in battle that I was on a real disadvantage. She was there the longest and was friends with most people there. She also had some REALLY good stats. She did die fighting however. Taking many tribal people on her way out. I built her a special place of rest, right beside her lover.Fay the new Head Cultist took over and boy was she good with her social stats (it was the main reason I picked her). She was a non-violent soul however and would never engage in combat. This wasn't a huge problem, but I like a social leader more than one with a huge bloodlust. Our numbers grew greatly as we went from a mere 7 people to now 12, all of them cultists. I also had a pack of 4 people, all of them had the traits of, cannibal, psychopath (I forget what it's called correct me if I'm wrong), and bloodlust. I had them wear black goat heads and differing robes. I called them the Spawn of Dagon and they wrecked♥♥♥♥♥ All except for one used melee and the one who didn't was their leader. His name was Sven and he was a ♥♥♥♥ing monster in both ranged and melee. He also liked getting hurt so...that was a plus...I guess. But I used the Spawn for more "covert" operations. They did win me the war when we assailed their fortress of♥♥♥♥♥♥and mud. Well it was properly built for an NPC village, but the faction leader was there and blah blah blah. The final battle was to begin.The best way to describe the fortress is a wooden castle. But that's...slightly inaccurate. I began the siege with drawing 5 runes outside the "walls". The first wave of Deep Ones got ♥♥♥♥ing obliterated. I didn't really anticipate the number of arrows they were packing...the short answer is...too many. As the waves of eldritch horrors crashed upon their walls my cultists waited for the right time to charge in. The Spawn of Dagon however took a differing route. They dug into the mountain for a flanking assault. We did get the jump on a few archers held up inside a little shack. And with that we gained a small, but valuable foothold within the fortress. And with that I constructed not 1, not 2, but 7 runes. The tide of Deep Ones was spooky, but it would be worth it as Deep Ones now streamed into the fortress taking out many archers and guards inside their humble abode. And with the storm gate open, but overflowing. The Deep Ones did end up dying, but the damage they caused was massive to the point where I just sent my army to deal with the rest. And with most the damage done I took who I could prisoner including the faction leader. And while the war was won a larger threat came to my colony and destroyed it. An avatar of great Cthulhu came in the night and just ♥♥♥♥ing ganked my colony to an early grave. And with that The Chosen were mushed into the dirt.And thus ends our tale. I will be back with more tales in the future my friends, but for now. I bid you goodbye.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								Imagine this: take some of the crisis management of FTL and mix it with some open-world resource-gathering survival aspects of Don't Starve.  Add a research tech tree, enough tools to stretch your creativity with time/resource/task management a little bit similar to Prison Architect, and throw in some hilarious and often tense character interactions.  Make the game easy enough to build mods for that the community runs wild and adds tons of fantastic content.  Then try something totally crazy and have the *story itself* be procedurally generated.  This doesn't sound like a great combination ot ideas to put into a single game, but it works so well it blows me away.  Everyone likes to share the stories they experienced, and below is my favorite.I created the entire crew of Firefly complete with quirks and relationships, then over a few years of game time had them carefully carve out a massive cave in the side of a mountain in the shape of the Serenity ship hull, acurrate in scale and layout to the "real" thing.  I was overjoyed when Mal and Inara hit it off right away and eventually got married, and Kaylee eventually found some romance with a wandering native she helped rescue.  They were really unhappy for a while until the crew quarters were finished with double-beds so they could finalle snuggle together at night.  It was a challenge protecting all the livestock from bandits and keeping the forest from burning during those dry thunderstorms.  But in the end, I love my crew.Here are a few of the notes from that game (mostly how Simon is terrible):-Day 4: Jon wanders into camp and joins up, looking for big game.  Over the years he gets his fill while fighting some maneater muffalo and lost his hand, and later while fighting a mad pack of rhinos he lost his nose and left leg, and his left eye later on defending against some raiders.  Poor guy.-Day 17: Jon broke and threw a tantrum because he was cold, because he slept in the freezer, like an idiot-Day 41: The god****ed rabbits are multiplying so fast they are eating all the grass and starving themselves, so we're butchering all that are starving, that'll teach 'em-Day 66: Simon, when rebuffed by Inara, went on a rage streak.  He didn't cause much damage because he's so weak. But he lost his right pinky when he picked a fight with one of my huskies.  Mal came to knock his a** out.-Day 67: Simon showing signs of cracking mostly because he's been turned down by Kaylee and Inara (who is married, what a jerk).  Yep, Simon is a little child and broke because of hideous environment.  He started attacking River, who just recovered from her own mental break and was still naked.  Janye knocked his a** out.-Day 68: Simon, being the bbaby that he is, goes berserk and attacks a husky again.  Zoe has none of his crap, disrespecing Mal's party, and punches him to the floor.  He can heal in bed during the party.-Day 72: Middle of the night some bugs spawned and wrecked the crew.  Booke lost a leg, everyone lost some blood.  Simon, once again, went berserk because he's a stupid child and couldn't handle it.  I hate that guy.-Day 101: Overnight a dry thunderstorm threatened to burn our fodder and livestock, tried putting it out.  Simon is a tard.  He keeps catching on fire while trying to put it out.  He is so damn useless.-Day 131: The crew discovers they can capture bandits and harvest organs from the prisoner to transplant into the crew (mostly Jon) to repair battle damage.-Day 135: We are no longer worried about harvesting organs.  So Wash threw a party.  Too bad we're going to harvest some more.-Day 139: Captured a new victim to harvest organs from, muwahaha.-Day 200'ish: The Serenity cave is finished.  There was a new alpha relesase that broke my save game unfortunately, and that was the end of that story.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 5
Early Access Review
								This game will imprint Murphy's Law into your brain forever.As a veteran of Dwarf Fortress, there have been many attempts at cloning the legendary game's masochistic "Fun" that grabs you like you just did a line and slaps you in the face, leaving you to beg for more. While I have logged many hours in Gnomoria and Towns, and other such games, they just have not been able to keep my attention for long. Whether it be poor AI, a feeling of general disconnect with the world, or just simply, lack of enough "Game" to be interesting, it seems like Rimworld has finally hit the bullseye.Hell, this game might even captivate me more than dwarf fortress at this point. With its absolutely beautiful soundtrack reminiscent of both Prison Architect's (Same composer, I think) and poking a teeny bit at the nostalgia for Firefly, the world feels both alive, and interactive. If you want to and you think you are up to snuff, you can siege an enemy town, picking off bandits with precision down to the finger. But beware, however powerful you feel you are, the game will always, and I mean ALWAYS cut you down to size. While I've found Randy Random, ironically, to be the most balanced, and the easiest of gamemodes, Playing him on rough and above is just as masochistic as picking Cassandra or Phoebe. Beware their lulls, they can and will destroy you without a second though. And you. Will. Love. It.Oh, and Workshop! And mods! Did I mention mods? I probably should have!TL:DR This game is crack cocaine, and in its Alpha state, holds its own against the current king of Colony games, Dwarf FortressYes. Yes. And Yes. This was my best purchase of 2016.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is an Alpha 15c review, which isn't code, that's just the version.  Obviously.Yawn, another early access game primed ready to disappoint when the devs decide to go spend their hard earned money on wine and cheap hookers (hold the wine).  I can already feel the inevitable sense of betrayal in the air.I hope not.  I really, really hope not.  This has quickly become one of my favourite games of all time.  Funny, sad, horrendous at times; few games have generated so many unexpected stories while I wasn't looking, and then slapped me round the face twice for not paying attention.  Like the time my bunch of colonists ran out of food in the middle of winter and ate the family dog, then a mad squirrel, then a lonely trader looking for some business.  We drank his beer though.  Like the time my colony set on fire and the internal temperature of the cabin hit over 2000 degrees, roasting my little minions alive while they desperately tried to put it out (please, devs, can we have vanilla fuses?)Graphically, it's reminiscent of prison architect, and you are a benevolent colony god staring down at your colonies burgeoning attempts to survive in this new world.  They cook, grow, mine, chop, and butcher their way across the map; hunting resources to build ever more complex stuff to vomit on when your 17 year old degenerate accidentally gives everyone food poisoning.  Like all sim management games, there is a steep learning curve, so fully expect your colonists to perish a lot in the early game, and quite frankly the end game.  The devs have provided a menu based tutorial helper for basic controls, as well as an opening tutorial, but it barely taps the surface of what can be done.  Learning how to prioritise work is a necessary feature you joyfully uncover for yourself, which is for the best because winter is looming and all your people are running around in pants throwing horseshoes at a wall, while the storehouse is filling with cloth.There are even NPC traders and raiders to deal with.  The former hang around your base and charge silver for items, the latter charge your defenses with increasingly worrisome weapons.  Set up turrets early on.  You won't regret it.  Then loot their corpses and keep the weapons, just don't let your starving colonists anywhere near the bodies (not a joke).All in all, I love the game.  It's fun, weird, and horrific in a fun and weird way.  Do yourself a favour; put on your crash pants and descend into the wilderness.  You won't regret it.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								I found this game had a steep learning curve. Thankfully the latest alpha release includes a tutorial and sort of an in-game "wiki" for different items. The game itself is beyond fantastic. This game is early access but honestly plays better than most stable live releases. Once you understand the game, you can customize virtually every aspect of your colony by setting gamerules--and the rich modding community allows for some truly epic possibilities.As for the gameplay itself, it functions as a 2D survival/base-builder game. You select a group of colonists who crashland on a "rimworld", a sort-of "backwater planet" on the edges of space. Your goal is to build a self-sustaining colony and ultimately construct another ship to leave the planet (although you can easily just sandbox this game and you really never have to leave). There are multiple difficulty settings, and there are even built-in debug tools if you enjoy cheating/pure sandboxing it.Gameplay includes building, hunting, combat, agriculture, production lines/crafting, trade, and even medicine. The latter is a particularly interesting aspect because not only can you treat injuries, you can perform surgeries on your colonists such as organ transplants, bionic upgrades--and you can even harvest prisoner's organs and sell them on the black market. Newest update lets you grow, manufacture and sell drugs, as well, if that's your type of thing.There really is no limit to this game. It's a complete time-sink and one of the most entertaining EA games I've ever owned.

								Rimworld is an overall fantastic game that really makes you feel like you got your money's worth after all is said and done. The game has a small learning curve when you're first getting started, but with the aid of their helpful tutorial and all of the publicly available walkthroughs and fan-made tutorials on the internet, it should be an easy curve to traverse. If you're on the fence about buying this game, I would highly suggest watching a few playthroughs on YouTube or elsewhere. It really is a "play your way" kind of game that is centered around basebuilding and colony survival. The developer continues to release amazing content month in and month out, and I believe he deserves all the support he can get.9/10

content:
Posted: January 31
Early Access Review
								You know, I love Rimworld. After getting to grips with the new engine (used by another very popular game of this genre) and the fact that the people have no feet or legs, (it seemed odd to me at first, but I got over it in the need to plant some corn!), I've clocked up over 600 hours of gameplay and I will recommend the game highly to anyone who asks my opinion of it. However, I have one bugbear that I find very frustrating, and that is, that every time the Dev releases an update, my established colonies are unplayable. I have to keep restarting, and since it is not a 'quick-play' type of game, in fact, it might take you weeks of gameplay to finally get to end-game, ie. building that spaceship to be able to get your colonists off the planet and back home where they belong, I've come to the conclusion that I might never get there. The stability of the framework seems shaky, and I never know when I log on, if I'm going to be able to load my current game or not. That said, I have soldiered on...because the actual gameplay is stable. I'm not experiencing mid-game crashes or other weird stuff happening. The stories that are created, as much by you as by the game itself, are always unique and entertaining. You just cannot make some of this♥♥♥♥♥♥up. :}It is also a builder, crafter and farmer's dream, particularly if you have signed on for a couple of the *choice* mods that extend that content. Lots and lots of equipable items for your little blobbies too. And, if you're a bit of a p*ssy like me, who doesn't like to wake up to find foaming-at-the-mouth hordes coming over the horizon while you stand there thinking 'Oh SH*T!!' then you can play in any number of more relaxed modes too, from 'peaceful' to 'OH MY GOD!'. Suits me just fine because it doesn't exclude me on the grounds of not wanting to have my colony's guts ripped out and handed to me in a bag after two weeks of carefully building my palatial base.  Your environment presents a danger too. I always like that attention to detail in a game. If a polar bear is hungry, he'll definitely be on the prowl for man-flesh. If it's snowing, your people will need warm clothes. If you mine just anywhere, you might hack into a secret cave full of mechanoids who can annihilate you where you stand. Lovely fun. All of it. Just find a way to stop breaking my games with the version updates, please. I feel quite stuck on repeat here, and it gets old eventually.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								I love rimworld. Even for being Early Access, in this case it doesn't mean the game is buggy, but could just use a few added features; which are easily added or supported at the moment with the incredible mod support in the workshop. RimWorld is the perfect balance between deep like dwarf fortress, but still usable in terms of UI and options. The UI notably is a lot like Prison Architect, and it is not a bad thing. It definitely serves its purpose. If there is anything I'd like more, it would be more handles for support in terms of mods and custom games. Let's say I'd like to play a scenario that is Star Wars themed; I'd like with that scenario to be included that it would be possible to have a set of characters with the famous names, maybe a visual themepack and custom occurences using the assets in the game. As well as maybe more "gameplay" ways. Like it would be possible to send my troops offmap, and load in a new map where I'd actually be raiding other nearby tribes in real time. Maybe a way to infiltrate as a sole pawn in an existing tribe and working my way up in more of an RPG perspective of things where the AI handles the colony. (I'm pretty sure looking at the manager mod could help in creating an AI). Though these are mere suggestions. For as the game goes, it's one of the only games on Steam I bought at full price, without regrets. Certainly the best game ever from Early Access.

Early Access Review
								Disclosure: I Kickstarted this game. Therefore I suppose I TECHNICALLY got the game for free? I have played several hundred hours before it was released on steam.The game is great. It is difficult and can murder you and your colony horribly but once you have an idea of the mechanics it can generally be manageable.The standard setup puts you in control of 3 stranded survivors after a horrible space ship crash. Fight disease, raiders, random events, raiders, food shortages, raiders, mechanical androids who want your sweet tasty flesh, raiders and raiders. Oh there are also raiders who occasionally show up to smash up your crap, kill your colonists and/or kidnap them. All in all the game is relatively well balanced if you use the normal AI storyteller (read ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ AI) but can be more challenging with the more difficult or random storytellers (massive ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ai)Cons: If you do not like the game constantly challenging you. It also hates you and your colonists. Especially the ones you named after your best friends.

Early Access Review
								Been playing Rimworld for around 9 months now and I love it.  The latest update (A14) has really smoothed out a lot of the game imo. & the introduction to steam will definitely make using mods easier - not that it was difficult before, but it's nice to have everything in one place and to easily add/update extra features. Even without the mods, it's a great game.  The devs being open and interacting with the players & modders makes rimworld feel like a community, even though you're playing alone. The story you create is always frustrating, heartwarming, shocking, and sometimes downright silly.Currently playing using the rich guy scenario, and as usual, rimworld has a funny sense of humour... My first four peeps are incapable of violence. Always excited to see what comes next!

content:
Posted: July 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								The One and only! TRUE PAIN SIMULATOR! You think it is about survival? Well, it is, but partly. It is a game about suffering from whatever your new narrator friend Randy throws at you. -Play as a early-medieval tribe, lost in the mountainous jungle-Find a good, spacious cave. Okayz, it is our home now.-Start making all the settlement stuff: rooms, beds, tables, corn farms, chess tables for the most clever of your tribesmen...-A small group of three peaceful travelers passes nearby-THEY HAVE A SHOTGUN, AMBUSH THEM! KILL THEM ALL, THE SHOTGUN WILL BE A NICE TROPHY FOR THE CHIEF!-Your chief now has a shotgun. And a kevlar vest. His tribespeople look at him in admiration-Start digging your cave's walls. Maybe you will find gold!-But you found a hidden, spacious room with two strange things, that say "Cryosleep casket" in the description.-And... OH MY GOD, THERE ARE 2 HOSTILE ROBOTS WITH CHAINGUNS NEAR IT! RUN!-Your tribespeople hid behind a corner, waited till the pursuing robots appear and bashed them to death with wooden clubs and spears. Those few blasts from the chief's shotgun have also helped-Found out you can't loot anything from the dead robots, carry them to the dumping area-Also found an "open" button on those cryocaskets in that room. All right, loot avaits!-Your chief, with 2 of his most trusted mates, open the cryocasket...-And find an angry, angry dude, with a shotgun, who instantly blast the chief to the stomach! Your chief's stomach is destroyed, but he is still alive, somehow-Chief's mates punch the man to the death, looting another shotgun.-Carry the bleeding chief to your dedicated hospital bed and treat his destroyed stomach. He will keep on living, somehow. Just have to get used to that hole in your belly.-While you were doing that, you find out a bug infestation in your storeroom, along with two bug hives.-The bugs near it were tiny, but were chipping away on the walls. Noone eats your walls and gets away with it!-You are confident. You killed two damn chaingun robots, you surely can deal with a few bugs!-All your tribesmen gathers near the storeroom and open the door. The chief's most trusted mate, now also with a shotgun, makes the first shot, killing one of the small bugs...-WRONG MOVE, MATE! Three huge starship-troopers-like bugs emerge from the hives and, disregarding your two hard-earned shotguns, slaughter the whole tribe-Experience butthurt10/10, shoulda bought some insecticide instead

Early Access Review
								I've put in a good 300 hours playing this game since I got it back in Alpha 9 (iirc), and I have one thing to say about this game: brilliant. It may be in early access but I still haven't experience a single crash whilst playing vanilla or any noticeable bug for that matter. The way Ludeon runs this as an early access with the ocasional big feature updates and smashing any and all bugs found inbetween means you don't get the continually festering buginess you find in many early access or even "fully released" games like minecraft where the devs just focus on killing the worst of the bugs before adding new features.All in all I would whole heartedly recommend this game to any of my friends or anyone who likes colony/city sims somewhat like what you got with firefly-edit: and if your not quite sold then I suggest searching for rimworld alpha 14 lets play on youtube and see what the game is like

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is basically Little house on the prarie with exploding rodents and automated turrents.If you like survival, base building/management, resource management, crafting, or any of those traits in a game, this is pretty much the best game out now. Think of it like The Sims or Prison Architect except you have to worry everything from growing enough crops to survive to alien bugs with plasma rifles invading. (That and most of your residents aren't in prison cells... Probably...) The type of game I wanted my whole life but didn't really know was missing until I played it. I used to be a fan of RTS games. But apparently, all I really wanted back then was games more like this. I've been playing it for years in alpha, and every time you think it seems done, the next update adds tons of exciting new features and makes it an even better game. Really exciting.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								So here I was, capturing a prisoner and putting him in my prison. Later on I add a second Prisoner. I decide to have some fun, Dexter style. What I do next is not for the faint of heart, John Snow goes to the prisoners and replaces one of the guys legs with peg legs, then takes out his kidney. I keep the body parts cold until a trader shows up to sell them. I then let the prisoner go free, while keeping his Kidney and legs. What about the last prisoner you ask? I let him off easy and just sold him to a Slaver for silver. After that happened, the other Survivors got really angry and mad because of my organ removal and selling a prisoner to the trader. Leason learned, You're Colony does not like it when you remove Organs of prisoners or sell them to slavers!Emprace the failure that you will face young jedi :)Enjoy Colony Management? Building and crafting stuff? Think Cannibalism and taking prisoners sounds fun? Like to die alot?  Pick this up!I have over 200 hours on this game before it came to steam (You could get it from the devs website or if you backed kickstarter). For me this is a game I can sit back and relax while I play, even though things get crazy and intense alot, things still manage to be enjoyable and some how relaxing.Reminds me of a cross between Prison Architect, Banished and Dwarf Fortress. You can set up bases, scavenge for things, craft stuff and take other people prisoner! Set up you're colony how ever you want! Allow each character to do only what you see fit.You can tell that the developer has had a blast working on this game and that alot of love, sweat and tears have gone into crafting this special game. The game also has a great AI storyteller that really effects the game, think of Left 4 Dead's game master as it tosses different nastyness at you.Make sure to get some beds up and keep everyone busy! Grab some snacks, create a game and get ready for a real blast! The game also has mod support and has come a long way over the last 3 years.  The main guy making this game has done a wonderful job so far and while some might say it is going to slow for them, for me it is perfect. He is taking his time to do things RIGHT. And every single update I look forward to and enjoy.The good far outweigh the bad in Rimworld, there are a few negatives or things that can be improved though. The UI can use some improvement and for some new players the game can be a bit tough to learn the ins and outs of (aka has a steep learning curve). There is so much good with this game though, the ideas are great, gameplay is fun and you can really be creative in this game if you want to. And lastly, as I mentioned before, I find the game very relaxing, even when I am getting attacked by bandits or animals, or some other crazy thing happening. This is a game worth taking a look at!Wonderful, unique game that I am SOOO glad to see has come to steam! One of the best indie games of the last 2-3 years for me personally and it isn't even finished yet. Support this wonderful game and this wonderful  fellow who has created this great game. Welcome to steam Rimworld!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								Having bought the game over 2 years ago, I can say that it has improved a lot and has, yet, much space to improve. Needless to say that, in its current state, it is already a solid and pretty good experience. Nevertheless, the steam's early access program will allow a better exposure of the game to gamers and will allow the developer, Tynan Sylvester, to make a great progress towards a final stage, which will, almost certainly, correspond to the players expectations/desires.I can affirm that Rimworld will NOT be one of those games that enter Steam Early Access with no intents of future upgrades, on the contrary it will be similar to Prison Architect (which in my opinion, was a model of what every game should be in Steam Early Access).When discussing what is great I would say:  Great graphics and artstyle;  Complex system interactions between colonists;  Lots of replayability;  The new scenario system;  Great moddability;  The commercial and faction system.Having this said, it is important to remind that this is still an Early Acess which means there are bugs, there will be with each new update and this is an unfinished product.Overall I had a great experience and would totally reccomend Rimworld!

content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								I don't usually bother writing reviews for games, but I bought this one a few days before the steam launch and many many hours of gameplay later i feel that I have to put something out there. This game is great (although you might end up still awake when the sun comes up occasionally). There are obvious graphical design influences from Prison Architect, but as soon as you start playing you realise that the similarity is really only skin deep. Building your colony can be very satisfying and straddles the gap between a building sim and a survival defense game. If you prefer the more base building aspects, or if you like the idea of dealing with multiple varied threats like diseases, raiding parties, rabid animals etc, both are available. Depending on which 'storyteller' you choose (part of the games difficulty settings), your first colony can run smoothly, gradualy growing and attracting more settlers as you grow food, mine rocks, build up your living quarters and defenses, or ... as mine did, a volcanic winter followed by some sort of nuclear fallout can drive your previously content survivors into deranged idiots, who attack each othr, strip off, run outside in the cold and eventually die.The game is also very complete for an 'early access' title, there is no aspect of the game which feels unfinished and although i'm sure some changes are to come, the game almost could be full release at the moment. If there is any aspect of gameplay missing, in my opinion it would be a little more management ability for your colony, such as the ability to set switches to be turned on / off at particular times etc.There are some decent mods out there too which add or improve various of the games features although some modded aspects have since gone on to be incorporated into the vanila game. Final verdict: Must give it a go. It is definitely worth the £22 / $30, and if you fancy supporting the devs, you can purchase it directly from the website to ensure they get most of your money.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you don't like Rimworld, I don't think you can be classed as human any more.Rimworld is one of the best possible games, and still it's not finished.It offers much of the depth of Dwarf Fortress, the artistic style of Prison Architect, and the moddability of both.Wraps it all up in a not-horrible User Interface, and then lets you fail spectacuarly.You will lose your colonists, often. It may be to a hoard of bloodthirsty elephants who leave your entire colony splattered with a mix of their blood and the blood of your colonists.It may be to a group of mechanoids falling out of the sky, and slaughtering your population.It may be to a tribal raid, many of whom you manage to slaughter before finally succumbing to their sheer numbers. It might even be to a toxic fallout that leaves your people trapped inside until the food and power run out.It could be to internal politics, or a prision break, or a host of other possibilities.But each time leaves a story, each story teaches you something new, and each new thing helps you eek towards finally building a starship, and fleeing the rimworld.Your wallet might not like it, nor will your girlfriend (unless you get her a copy too).But Rimworld really is a game well worth the price of admission.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								The best possible combination of Dwarf Fortress in Space with a heavy space-western Firefly element. This game is everything right with PC gaming in one affordable package, and the community workshop is hyper-active even while the game is in early access. It has everything it says on the box, and a unique feel that really hooks you.Just get it, and make sure you don't have to be anywhere important for a few days.On a side note, my little starting survivor band had an aging beauty queen who refused to do physical labor and treated all the others like trash. Poetic justice was served when a rabid wolf bit her nose off and everyone's opinions suddenly dropped due to disgust and hatred. There's that level of detail, and yes, you will insist on telling random strangers about every last bit of it.Seriously, if you've read this far then you've missed the important bit. Go get it and make your own story instead of reading all of ours.
