Early Access Review
								The Gods were angry.For thousands of years the gods had watched over the peaceful tribe, when the tribe prayed for rain and good health, the Gods answered, for the tribe prayed to no one but them. And for thousands of years the tribe gazed galliantly upwards, looking to no one but the gods. But one day, the tribe cast their eyes upon a giant metal ship.The sky people brought them machines to guard their fields, weapons to hunt bigger animals, and in turn the tribe gifted the sky people all of their treasures. The treasures that they promised to the Gods.Furious with the tribes betrayal, the gods struk out. Possessing the giant machines the sky people brought, the Gods slaughtered the tribe, burned the village. Killed men and babies alike. The world was cast into a week long eclipse; for the Gods could not bear to look upon those they had once loved so. Five tribespeople managed to escape under the darkness. They ran far away, into the desert. Desperate to escape their creators wrath. As the hopeless survivors fumbeled with broken tools in the quiet of the night, one man rose to the challange to lead his comrades out of their misery. His name, was Val Chief. Under his protective gaze, the few lost soles under his guidance soon began to build a flurishing village. One with a large central hut where all the tirbespeople could laugh and eat in safety. Soon, even the Gods could not ignore their sucess, the eclipse lifted, and the tribes people were free to enjoy the sun once more. As the years went on, Val fell in love with a woman; Seara, the village healer. Their love blossemed like the endless rose fields the tribespeople had planted outside their main hut. Seara had many suitors, the strong warrior Flint, protested his love for her almost every day, but she always stayed loyal to Val. In the heat of the summer, they married. Val and Seara lived happily within the safety of their new tribe for many seasons.And as the village grew, so did Vals generosity. He wanted nothing more than to help all the lost souls he found wandering through the desert, after all, he was a hopeful optimist. So when a man called out, desperate for someone to save him from the vicious bandits chasing him, Val instantly offered him sanctuary. The five survivors gathered their spears and bows, then headed into cover. The bandits soon came raiding, they shot at the tribes people with their metal bows. As Seara bravely charged the nearest bandit with her club, another attacked her. Before anyone could come to save her, she was shot. Dead. Enraged, the surivors charged the bandits and drove them off, injuring many on both sides in the process. The two standing villagers took the injured to their beds, and the dead to their graves.Seara was buried within the field of roses. Every day, many of her friends would come to meditate by her grave. But not Val. Unable to face the dire thuth, that his generisity had cost him the love of his life, Val hid in his room, nursing his pain. Both physical and mental, until he could take it no more. His wife was dead. He was alone. It broke him. One day, blinded by pain, Val grabbed his spear and took to the main hut with a deathly glint in his eyes. He murdered the dog first. Then the turtle. And as he fumed within the walls of the hut he worked so hard to build, his friends gathered outside, bows ready. They waited outside, hoping upon hope that the beserk rage would fade, but Val had other ideas. He charged outside and began hacking his friends. They were forced to stop him. A spear through the heart. Val fell, dead. They buried him beside his beloved wife, surrounded by roses, they were together once more. The tribe lived on, continued to flurish, but the story of Val and Seara was never forgotten.A story told by the scenario system within rimword.10/10 - Made me cry over pixels.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								What a great little fun game. This has all the management you could want and it goes for realism. After a few failed games of my settlers dying to heatstroke, pirates, and starvation, I finally had the hang of it. I had one of my founding colonists get her jaw and leg shot off in a pirate raid, she was in bed for days, until I gave her a peg leg and a denture. Now she can walk again! Her husband is a little repulsed by her disfigurement, but at least she's alive. It's pretty difficult, even on the easier settings, but you learn quick how to survive. I'm growing hops to make beer to keep my people happier. You have to hoard food once you have a few extra people, it will go fast. Build a wooden storage room with 2 ACs. Keep it cold so it doesn't spoil. Power is important. There are many ways to generate it.I was finally able to get a leg up on the raiders by building a single Assult Rifle once I had the means. This rifle tore into these thugs like butter, in the right hands. I also had sandbags placed outside of my base to defend. I lost people and had a few injuries and scares, but I survived and expanded into a large compound with steel and stone walls. In addition to the assault rifle, I now had a shotgun, sniper rifle, incendiary weapon, pwd (smg?), plenty of pistols and shivs. Made a longsword for the guy who prefers brawling up close. I feel OK when 4-5 pirates come knocking on our doors.You forget this is an early access game because of how functional it is now. I'm sure they will work out the few kinks and bugs I've seen, but as it is, it's a hectic fun survival strategy game. For now, there is still more to do...

content:
Posted: September 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								Ahh Rim World. Such beautiful stories you tell. You've earned my recommendation wholeheartedly. The following story is from my first playthrough. I’ve done about 5 now, each with their own beautiful character and story arcs, complete with social challenges. It’s amazing to watch it unfold and I’m excited for the future of RimWorld.Freedom Colony:It was a nice day in Freedom. Hammer the Oaf, freshly stranded had met up with a few lucky other colonists. Silver, the fiery, genetically grown combat medic was the first person he met on this god forsaken planet.. She was a after the war geneticist, and Hammer was in love with her. Unfortunately though, Hammer was ugly. Hammer loved people and animals the most out of anything in the world. His true love however, was Silver. He tried to talk to her almost every day, but his voice was so annoying and he was so ugly, that she became very irritated and would insult him. He felt bad so he went off to find an animal companion to cheer himself up. Hammer, the Oaf that he was, found a playful adult cougar. NOT THAT KIND OF COUGAR KEEP READING. He wanted to be best friends! But the cougar mauled the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of Hammer, and his right arm was shredded as ♥♥♥♥.   The other colonists tried to save his life, but because of the severe infection, it was deemed his right arm would have to be amputated. Silver the Combat Medic/Geneticist( and far over qualified to save Hammer), horrified by watching hammer be mauled and also already on the edge of mental breakdown due to Hammers repeated advances, finally snapped. She ran off into the night, leaving all her clothes behind. She took the pistol, however. Hammer the Oaf lay on the operating table. The operation was to be performed by the only person qualified to operate……. José.  José, the agriculture and architecture extraordinaire took it upon himself to save Hammers life. So he got to work. Hammer emerged from the operation to find that somehow his liver had been punctured (wtf José really???) and his torso was badly cut. He soon died, and the other colonists minds broke as well.  It was chaos and for one night, the were all…...free….…. Running off into the wilderness they somehow found themselves, lost out there, among the wildlife. I wept for Hammer. For Silver. For José, you beautiful ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. For the less important characters without names, many of whom died horrific deaths as they lost their minds snapped like twigs with the weight of the void pressing down on them.10/10 I didn’t know if it would be worth $30.It is.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								My three colonists started off ok, but being new to this game, I was still rounding the learning curve, and times were tough. Vladamir, the least useful of my colonists, was a medieval lord trained in the subtleties of swordplay, gunnery, nobility, and er... not much else. Lumpy was a former slave, and Soarna a fledgling artist. All pulled their weight while vladamir just sorta wandered around a lot, breathing all creepy like (no joke, creepy breathing was one of his traits). One day Lumpy came across a mysterious steel structure, of course I ordered her to take down it's steel walls, and lo and behold behind it was a derelict cryopod and a giant spider for some reason. Naturally I sent in vladimir with his gunnery skill and lumpy to dispatch this beast. It got ugly fast and lumpy suffered a nasty gash on her neck, but even more curiously, during the firefight the cryopod somehow opened and a space soldier emerged to help battle this beast. He was almost immediately mauled, and I tried to rescue him, but apparantly you can't rescue someone who is designated as an 'enemy' by the game. So I just left him in a pool of blood in shock. According to his character profile, he was a massochist and loved pain, so I assumed it was probably for the best. Meanwhile a hungry bear began to terrorize my colony and killed Vladamir's beloved pet fox. Upon return I had vlad kill the bear, but he took the death of his fox pretty bad. Furthermore the colony was very low on food and I didn't know how to butcher animals at this point, so I instructed vlad to eat the bear, assuming he would make the proper preparations, but no, he literally dragged the bear corpse to the nearby kitchen table and chowed down. About 1/4 of the way through he appeared to become disgusted with himself for eating a corspe raw and his mood dropped even further. Meanwhile his friend Lumpy's neck wound became infected and she almost immediately died. All of these misfourtunes, coupled with poor living conditions seemed to be too much for vladamir, so he promptly grabbed his rifle, and went "berserk" and ran off into the forest, I can only imagine, babbling incoherently and breathing creepily all the while. There wasn't much I could do at this point, so I shrugged and returned to my last remaining colonist, and attempted to get the colony in order as best I could. Days later I had completely forgotten about Vladamir and went about finding him to make sure he wasn't causing too much trouble in his frenzied state. Well I found him.. or what was left of him.. his corpse was lying in a giant pool of blood, and his rifle was a couple meters away.. using my superb detective skills, as well as the games combat and health logs I was able to piece together what had happened. It seemed that Vladamir had come across the path of a warg.. a very large warg.. and in his berserk stupor, had decided that this was a great target to unleash his fury on. I'm not even sure if he managed to get a shot off because according to his health log, both arms had been ripped off, as well as both of his legs, his torso mauled, his head decapitated, and his actual cause of death was listed as "massive bloodloss". I could only assume the warg was probably ok. And apparantly Vladamir was kind of a♥♥♥♥♥♥because my remaining survivor appeared to have a mood boost resulting from Vladamir's death. In fact my colony is doing better than ever since Vladamir died.Great game, 11/10, would berserk again.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								So it started out alone, just a fancy rich explorer out to site see on her own. After building a rudimentary base she met a wandering mercenary who decided to help her and settle down. Not long after they fell in love and were married. One by one thier little outpost grew from wandering warriors to escape pods crashing down. All was well until one of those escape pods let out a wounded man call Obrian. He was very helpful at first, a very good cook who was loyal and true friend to all. But he had a secret. Lying deep inside his mind was a weakness built in to psychological tremors. A few months go by, rain and heat. Storms and raids. He weathered them all until a mysterious whisper crept into his mind. Slowly after several days of fighting his urges, he finally broke. In a berzerk rage he attack Merc and beat him to death. This lead to his wife Lumi shooting Obrian and incapacitating him. Mourning her husbands death she went to bed that night with another female friend for comfort. In the morning they euthanized Obrian because he was still on the edge of breaking again. Then suddenly Lumi was the one to break. Maybe it was the grave made next to her bed, or the strange friend sleeping next to her, but she went on a rampage and shot everyone. Unable to bear any of it anymore, she went and attacked a boomalope hoping to die in a sudden explosive death, but was instead knocked unconsious as she slowly died to the elements. No I didnt make this up, I was genuinely sad when Merc died :(

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								I already had hundreds of hours in this game before it dropped on Steam, so let me just say right away that it's definitely worth $30.00RimWorld is a game about managing the survivors of a crashed spaceship as they land in a hostile, unexplored wilderness.  Similar to a (less detailed) Dwarf Fortress with a Prison Architect aesthetic, RimWorld is a very comfy game, while also being challenging and addicting.  My only real complaint is how easy vanilla is, but the game has a very healthy mod scene and there are a lot of ways to expand the game or increase difficulty with mods.9/10 and gets better with every update.  Pick up a copy today!

content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								The best possible combination of Dwarf Fortress in Space with a heavy space-western Firefly element. This game is everything right with PC gaming in one affordable package, and the community workshop is hyper-active even while the game is in early access. It has everything it says on the box, and a unique feel that really hooks you.Just get it, and make sure you don't have to be anywhere important for a few days.On a side note, my little starting survivor band had an aging beauty queen who refused to do physical labor and treated all the others like trash. Poetic justice was served when a rabid wolf bit her nose off and everyone's opinions suddenly dropped due to disgust and hatred. There's that level of detail, and yes, you will insist on telling random strangers about every last bit of it.Seriously, if you've read this far then you've missed the important bit. Go get it and make your own story instead of reading all of ours.

								This game is simply amazing. Although in alpha this game is remarkable, the graphics are amazing and the way it runs is just brilliant. Rimworld is a survival game where you start with a 2 bandages, a rock and a torch, you then proceed to gather materials and make a house. As the game goes along it gets harder to make items which gives it a longer play time. The PvP aspect is amazing as a half naked man can run over a hill and demolish you which is pretty funny in my experience. I rate it 9/10 just as I feel the updates need to be a little faster.EDIT NEW RIMWORLDThis game just gets better not only are the devs dedicated enough to rework the game completely, they update it every week! The graphics are god like and the PvP is even better than before although a half naked man killing you, usually involves a bow or a spear and you end up crying in a corner. I rate it 10/10 Game Of The Year, Nice work Ludeon Studios	 :D

content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have been playing this game since alpha 3.   I estimate, at the time of this posting, that I have put over 500 hours into this game if you include all the different alpha versions.  This game has come a long way and I expect there will be even more to come.   As the game is now, alpha 14 as I write this, it could be considered a complete game when you consider the amount of content.   It will keep you busy for hours.   At $30, it's well worth it.Basically you start with a few resources and a handful of colonists and eventually grow your colony into something much more.   The end game idea is to build a ship and escape the planet you are on.   But the enjoyment is actually building up your colony and defending it against exterior threats.  There are many threats including raiders, weather events, and starvation/exposure (in the more diffcult biomes like desert and tundra).  Each threat is unique and has systems in the game to deal with them.  You can play any game type you like.   Meaning, you can deactivate threats you find annoying or unbalanced.  You can choose your biome as well.   Perhaps you want to play an easy biome with more raiders?   Or you want to play on the Ice sheet with minimal raiders?  It's up to you.At the end of the day Rimworld would be labeled a Basebuilder when it comes to genre.   But in reality, there is so much to it than that.  And even if you want to use a mypopic definition like "Basebuilder" when classifying Rimworld that's fine.   Because even within that narrow definition, Rimworld would be the best "Basebuilder" I have ever played.

Early Access Review
								Was browsing on steam and saw this game...Looked interesting and decided to give it a go.Day 1, Touch down with 3 Survivors (Mother and daugther) + Emo girl +Pet Husky Day 2, Mum goes hunting and got injured....Hospitalised and stays in bedDay 3-5, couldn't figure out how to cure Mum's infection and sadly she passed away :( Buried her in a grave nearby..Day 6, accidentally slaugthered Pet husky:(Meanwhile whilst learning the game, managed to fend off raiders...The remaining days, the daughter suffers from severe depression due to the loss of her mum and pet husky:(...she goes on crazy naked walks and refuses to work!!!! A new wanderer joins the colony. We captured a raider and tried to recruit him... Day 14(or so)Food supplies weren't managed well(people were STARVING!!!) and Crazy daughter decided it was a good idea to eat the rotten corpse of a slained raider.....She went phycho and attackes her fellow colonists!Had to order Emo girl to gun her down! It wasn't an easy order to give!Thank goodness she was shot unconcious..she was brought back to life but her right arm was severly infected.....was going to give the order to amputate.....BUT HELD OFF! The depressed daughter recovers completely but still suffer from the loss of her mother....mean while our prisoner breaks down the door and attacks the colonist. He had to be put down!To Be Continued......8 Hours later I have to say I am hooked(but sadly have work the next day)! Very entertaining game indeed and well done to the devs.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								Please note I have played many, many hours of this game from pre-steam alphas.THIS GAME IS DOPE. The basics of the game involve you building a village (I say village because of the new system which means you can play as a tribe rather than colonists) and helping your villagers/colonists suvive by building shelter, making enough food for people to eat and defending your villagers/colonists from the dangers that the game throws at you.There are 3 different 'stroytellers' for you to chose from, Cassandra Classic where the challenge level increases over time in a classic style of games, Pheobie Chillax where the focus is more on basebuilding and the size and wealth of your village/colony increases the difficulty level but you have more time to prepare and recover or Randy Random where most of the rules don't apply and the RNG gods have free reign to massively p*** you off by swamping your village/colony with ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ pirates that somehow manage to cut off the arm of my best colonist by punching them. (How does my best colonist get her arm punched off? HOW DOES THAT HAPPEN???????) However there is still an aspect of difficulty increasing overtime, just it can happen really suddenly.Tame animals, kill other animals, build up a city and unlock all of the researches with the intent of flying away on a spaceship you build (except most people don't do this unless a new alpha is due to be released and they want to finish their current game) all whilst surviving the cruel and harsh worlds and also the cruel and harsh raiders. Take them prisoner in order to recruit them or slaughter them where they stand in order to minimse injury. One thing with the game though is that a lot of people (myself included) would mod this game a lot because the mods add soooo much to the game which can be good or bad depending on your opinions on moddingBut I promise if you like games like dwarf fortress you will like this and even if you don't this game is a load of fun

Early Access Review
								Rimworld is a Colony survival / management game, with some incredibly deep and meaningful mechanic systems that mesh together to make a very very awesome game if you are into this genre.Ive played Rimworld easily for 100+ hours prior to it releasing on steam, and from the moment I started playing it when I first found out about the game (which at this point i dont remember how i found it, maybe kickstarter) every time you play the game, there are very good chances of you being put into an interesting situation where you have to make a decision that has implications down the road.It is always a pleasure to start a new colony as the new alpha versions get released since they are usually packed with new features and systems in an already complex yet simple game. Simply starting my colony in this steam release of alpha 14 show me something ive never encounted before, which makes for an interesting story. (my three colonists happen to be a mother and her 2 sons) I could go on and on about the game, but in the end, its your own personal journey through the game that will be very unique and hopefully you find interesting.There is base building, farming, combat, injury, trading, pets, disastors. seasons, temprature, reasearch, crafting, all woven together so elegantly!

content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								Been playing since Alpha 2, and this "early release" is much farther along and very playable, unlike many others who hit Steam.Maybe you'll build your batteries outside. When they blow up in the rain, and you watch colonists die in the fire trying to put it out, or run screaming away only to return to desolation, you'll know what you did wrong.Maybe your colonists just aren't skilled enough to farm and mine basic subsistence, and you watch them slowly go mad as they refuse to do the work necessary to survive.Maybe you got too lax with the squirrels in your camp, and one goes rabid, biting your best medic, which is the last straw for her - what with the bedroom being too small and the food being too boring - and causes a psychotic break. In her rampage, she gives your best fighters concussions, and you couldn't get anyone to subdue her before they're all bleeding, dying, and the medic is passed out in the wilderness dying of stavation.Maybe a lightning strike happens to hit the one wire connecting your turret bank, right before a bandit assault. Or angry natives bring a rocket launcher, creating a hole in your defenses that you thought were solid. You survive the attack, but the lack of preperation, injuries and death, and loss of supplies are just too much for your colony to recover from.Maybe, maybe you'll lay the foundations for a thriving trade outpost. A Deadwood in space. A Babylon 5 on a planet's surface. A spot of stability in the messy frontier of space.Whatever happens, you will learn what went wrong, what detail you missed, what you can improve for next time, as you watch your colony wrestle survival and sanity, before closing their book and opening another.Difficulty and story style options, along with previewing and rerolling your colonist(s), helps you start off into the game you want to play.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've played this game for about a year and it's easily tied as my favorite colony sim with Gnomoria. If you have any imagination or tendency for headcanoning things, this is the game for you. Of all the colony sims I've played, this one is amongst the most user friendly and sufficiently detailed without being overwhelming. I look forward to more mods and content as time passes :DLet me now tell you the tale of the town of Hurra...Hurra started as a small crashsite wherin the only survivors were a planetary settler, someone's livein roommate, and the psychotic butcher. The butcher brought in loads of animals, each struck down with a single blow and chopped them into bits, the roommate cooked the bits and kept the settlement clean, and the settler did everything else.The colony grew steadily, marked only with one person of particular interest, a scoundrel by the name of Mickey 'Ye' Huang. Having been a minstrel most of his life, Mickey was drunk, lazy, and incapable of any meaningful labor. But, Mickey was good for a laugh and liked to carve statues from wood that rich people from other worlds liked to buy so Mickey pulled his considerable weight. One day Mickey carved a legendary statue of incredible realism that depicted the death of his fellow colonists and a great fire. Despite how beautiful the statue was, (or Mickey clamed it was anyway) the rest of the colony hated it and marked it for export as it seemed to be an expression of madness. An expression of madness... or prophetic vision?Hurra was a peaceful place, the peace only interrupted by the occasional wistless bandit taken captive and 'convinced' to join or be harvested for organs, and the infrequent mass boomalope chain explosion. Until one day 'it' arrived. It poisoned the land, killing crops and trees, and before the colonists could mobilize to deal with the metal monstrosity, another appeared, this time affecting their very minds. In assaulting the twin metal aberrations, many died, and those who were not killed were badly wounded. Immediately after the great calamity, the bandits whom had made Hurra rich and populous arrived in force, slaying with abandon, and burning that which could not be stolen. The sole survivor of this madness was a terribly old man afflicted with dementia, cataracts, and a bad back who had been welcomed by the colonists only a week prior as a means of trying to alleviate the guilt they had felt in inflicting attrocities upon even those who had meant them harm. For a day or two, the old man, kept it together and dug graves for the original settlers, unil overcome by grief, he beat his dog to death. Now with bleeding and infected wounds from his expired companion, he lay in the viscera covered hospital, slowly waiting to die. But before he could finish Mickey's prophecy, a wanderer came upon the colony and for reasons unknown even to him, he decided to join the colony. That man was former pirate captain, Tater Strahmn.Tater heard the stories of Hurra, buried the old man, and rebuilt. In the years that followed, he lost all of his natural limbs and eyes defending his belief for a brighter future. Now today Hurra is a safe place where most are welcome, where slavery and organ trafficing are illegal. Tater stands above it all as a watchful cybernetic god clad in power armor, armed to the teeth, and followed by a horde of huskies. The only remnants of the old Hurra in the Pax Tatus are the graveyard where many colonists now come for silent contemplation after work, history having been rewritten to make the fallen into heroes, and a slightly burnt but beautiful statue in the primary cafeteria made by a forgotten artist prophesying the end of the world.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								What a great little fun game. This has all the management you could want and it goes for realism. After a few failed games of my settlers dying to heatstroke, pirates, and starvation, I finally had the hang of it. I had one of my founding colonists get her jaw and leg shot off in a pirate raid, she was in bed for days, until I gave her a peg leg and a denture. Now she can walk again! Her husband is a little repulsed by her disfigurement, but at least she's alive. It's pretty difficult, even on the easier settings, but you learn quick how to survive. I'm growing hops to make beer to keep my people happier. You have to hoard food once you have a few extra people, it will go fast. Build a wooden storage room with 2 ACs. Keep it cold so it doesn't spoil. Power is important. There are many ways to generate it.I was finally able to get a leg up on the raiders by building a single Assult Rifle once I had the means. This rifle tore into these thugs like butter, in the right hands. I also had sandbags placed outside of my base to defend. I lost people and had a few injuries and scares, but I survived and expanded into a large compound with steel and stone walls. In addition to the assault rifle, I now had a shotgun, sniper rifle, incendiary weapon, pwd (smg?), plenty of pistols and shivs. Made a longsword for the guy who prefers brawling up close. I feel OK when 4-5 pirates come knocking on our doors.You forget this is an early access game because of how functional it is now. I'm sure they will work out the few kinks and bugs I've seen, but as it is, it's a hectic fun survival strategy game. For now, there is still more to do...

content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								I'm not always write a steam review. But when I do it's for a great game!I brought this 3 days ago out of curiosity, it's Friday. I thought I would took 30 mins to skim it a bit.. so I started my first colony of 3 people, Lumi - the Hunter, Andy - engineer and a girl, Rose,  she was a scientist. It was going pretty well at the start.. we found a steel structure and made the main building out of it. Andy was basically a slave worker, he did everything from building to hauling potatoes. Lumi with a rifle hunted small animals but after awhile we realized that hunting is not a reliable meal source so I assigned her to help Rose in farming.One day, the wanderer name Vector came to join. From his bio, he was a kingpin. I was sure aware that he cannot be trusted but at that moment, we need some protections, a guy who can shoot. I also gave him Lumi's rifle, the best weapon we had. He spent most days standing and walking around, not helping at all.We got raid for the first time by a mullet girl name Rani. Vector easily shot her down, she was injured but we didn't want to kill her so instead we captured her inside a 2x3 square blocks room. I asked Rose to take a good care of her, she then convinced and joined us. It's all good, 5 people in this small community. But... Vector, that guy complained about our only one shared bed room. My intention was only to protect everyone, it's the a building!! we simply can't afford the somewhere this strong. He didn't get me and went berserk and hurted Rose so I made Rani shoot him. both got badly injured. It's so sad that we cannot help them, they infected and need a medical care. Andy and Lumi tried but nothing effective.Rose died 3 days after that, Andy buried her on the other side of the hill. Few days later, Vector died but no proper grave for him, not after what he did, we dumped his corpse on the field and let it rot. It's a sad time, the first 3 were close friends, Lumi and Andy often visited Rose grave. Rani was surprisingly good to us, she also not helping the labour works but she was a good friends who dealt with traders and travellers. Our colony was advancing, we got a solar panel, the electric stove and a full set of dinner table. Lumi's not a good cook but at least we didn't have to eat raw foods anymore.The happy period was short, raiders came to attack, 3 guys with bow and rifle. I knew at the start that we couldn't defeat them but decided to fight anyway  because this is our home!!!! We fought well indeed, Rani killed 2 guys, the bowman and the one with a club, another one ran away. But all 3 got injured from the fight. We had no medical supplies and Andy.... died from blood loss.Why him? he was the only who endured all the pains, he lost a friend and yet still keep fighting for the community without complaining. I just...  can't play it anymore.Then I checked the clock (in real life), It has been 14 hours straight.Ok, now let me conclude,The game is so additive that you can easily lost track of time. While playing, I find my myself more and more connected with what I built. I love how the game let you write and enjoy your own story. It's say "EARLY ACCESS" but doesn't feel that way, it looks optimized even on the largest map. The devs sure to have future plans for it and I'm looking forward to that.just buy it already!!!!!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								Ahh Rim World. Such beautiful stories you tell. You've earned my recommendation wholeheartedly. The following story is from my first playthrough. I’ve done about 5 now, each with their own beautiful character and story arcs, complete with social challenges. It’s amazing to watch it unfold and I’m excited for the future of RimWorld.Freedom Colony:It was a nice day in Freedom. Hammer the Oaf, freshly stranded had met up with a few lucky other colonists. Silver, the fiery, genetically grown combat medic was the first person he met on this god forsaken planet.. She was a after the war geneticist, and Hammer was in love with her. Unfortunately though, Hammer was ugly. Hammer loved people and animals the most out of anything in the world. His true love however, was Silver. He tried to talk to her almost every day, but his voice was so annoying and he was so ugly, that she became very irritated and would insult him. He felt bad so he went off to find an animal companion to cheer himself up. Hammer, the Oaf that he was, found a playful adult cougar. NOT THAT KIND OF COUGAR KEEP READING. He wanted to be best friends! But the cougar mauled the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of Hammer, and his right arm was shredded as ♥♥♥♥.   The other colonists tried to save his life, but because of the severe infection, it was deemed his right arm would have to be amputated. Silver the Combat Medic/Geneticist( and far over qualified to save Hammer), horrified by watching hammer be mauled and also already on the edge of mental breakdown due to Hammers repeated advances, finally snapped. She ran off into the night, leaving all her clothes behind. She took the pistol, however. Hammer the Oaf lay on the operating table. The operation was to be performed by the only person qualified to operate……. José.  José, the agriculture and architecture extraordinaire took it upon himself to save Hammers life. So he got to work. Hammer emerged from the operation to find that somehow his liver had been punctured (wtf José really???) and his torso was badly cut. He soon died, and the other colonists minds broke as well.  It was chaos and for one night, the were all…...free….…. Running off into the wilderness they somehow found themselves, lost out there, among the wildlife. I wept for Hammer. For Silver. For José, you beautiful ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. For the less important characters without names, many of whom died horrific deaths as they lost their minds snapped like twigs with the weight of the void pressing down on them.10/10 I didn’t know if it would be worth $30.It is.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								Friends said I'd love this game.  I watched many YouTube playthroughs but they seemed long and boring.  I was not impressed.  Eventually, peer pressure got the best of me so I bought it.  Though I don't have many steam hours, I probably have 300 hours having bought from Ludeon.   It is an excellent game rich with content.  While I enjoy building a strong base with traps and mazes for raiders, What I want to concentrate on in this review is the content.What the videos don't convey well to someone who has never played RimWorld before is the attachment you have for certain characters in the game.  You will rely on your favorites to keep your colony alive.  When the inevitable happens and one of them loses a leg or worse dies, it changes your whole strategy.  You may decide to scrap the game and start over.  You may try to bribe a prisoner to join your colony.  One colonist can mean the difference between success and failure.  As I said, there is content on top of content.  See a statue in a room?  Take a look at it, each one tells a different story.   And that's just a simple example.  Each character feels a certain way about all other characters and vice versa.  Think that doesn't matter?  It does.  What other video game have you ever played where you cared whether two characters hated each other or not?  In this game you will.  You'll celebrate the former enemies who mend fences.  You'll curse when a colonist loses his spouse.  That not enough?  Every action has a reaction.  Is one colonist highly skilled at medicine, but making many mistakes?  Have you checked to see if he's drinking on the job?  Many weapons have their own stories too.  And so do the tombstones.  Many are hilarious.  To conclude, if you are sitting on the fence about whether to buy or not.  I'd recommend it to people who like building games.  I don't know what games to compare it to.  It has alot of the traits of Craft the World, resource management like Sim City, Banished (though it's far more entertaining IMO) and maybe some Age of Empires.  I don't think the let's play videos can do it justice until you actually learn the game.

content:

Early Access Review
								Ok, so i have played this game from that first alpha/beta stage, i am actually not sure what it exactly was. Right from the start, i saw the potential this game had. Becouse of this game, i have an account on patreon. I put my money and my trust in this game, and boy, it delivered.While still being in alpha, it offers tons of content, i admit, my last full game was around the 12 version i think, i simply dont have time for it now, but its awesome to watch it grow and becoming better and better with every update, not mention the content made from normal ppl. There is that certain atmosphere when its night and raining outside and you just watch your colonist go to sleep after the day of another hard work. When you plan the working schedules etc. and then you see it work, when you colony grows to be bigger and bigger and then it will get stomped by crazy AI. When you take a prisoner in to the colony who has a brain damage (i think she had literally bullet in her brain) and i in that version of the game, i could not fix it.  So i had to replace all of her limbs by high-tech prosthesis and she could atlest clean the base from dirt and stuff. Its a generator of great stories, that i can tell you.Of course, its not for everyone, so better check it on youtube etc. and make your own opinion.And now its on Steam!!! Hell yea!

content:
Posted: August 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								A tragic story of survival, friendship, and love on an unknown planet... Crash land on a flourishing landscape Begin the grueling task of gathering resources and building shelter Rescue multiple survivors of fallen rescue pods and convince them to join the cause Despite all the hard work, two survivors declare their love and are planning a wedding! A chapel is built specifically for the occassion The wedding night is upon us, and everyone gathers ALERT! Raiders are incoming! The bride, a skilled gun slinger, rushes off with the others to defend their home In a blur of gunfire and smoke, the bride takes a shotgun blow to the chest and is instantly DEAD! The dust settles and one of the raiders remains alive in the dirt, barely breathing The groom quietly walks up to the fallen raider and empties his gun, avenging his would-be wife I stare at my monitor and quietly exit the game - holy sh** what just happened?After only 20+ hours of gameplay, I thought this was just a basic build-n-survive type game. But you start to become attached to your survivors and then it becomes personal. Fiona (the bride) will not be forgotten!8/10 - No regrets buying this game. Will definitely play again! Looking forward to updates/patches that will enhance the game further.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
Product received for free
Early Access Review
								The dev team described the game as "Dwarf Fortess meets Firefly" and after playing for several hours, I can agree.General Concept:Hands-off unit direction (You give them a task, and someone will get to it.. when they're ready!), as you try to achieve more goals, starting from basic survival, to escaping the planet by building a ship, and dealing with random events that can either help you survive, or make your life hell.Pros:- Random Gen World- Small to Large gameplay areas- Customizable challenge/gameplay settings- Easy Start/Hard to Master- A lot of control over the base building aspects of the game- Every character has it's own personality, wants, needs and desires that you need to account for.Cons:- No direct unit control (w/exception for combat)- Random Gen World doesn't always spawn with needed resources (you are limited by in-game trade rng)- Every character has it's own personality, wants, needs and desires, and will take care of them in the order they want, not the order that might make the most sense.- Maps are currently only a single 'layer'- Single PlayerGameplay Overview:Dwarf Fortress is a good example of how the game plays, and what you can generally expect.  If you're carfeul about how you assign tasks, you can 'force' the AI to do certain things first, but at the of the day, if the character wants to sit and watch the clouds more than cook their food.. they're going to go hungry while enjoying the view!Release 14 introduces new modes expending on the core game, often increasing the challenge to the game (one scenario has you start with 1 character, instead of the normal 3), but ultimately is just a variation on the core game.  14 also introduces intergrated Workshop support for custom scenarios you build, which allows for much easier sharing of the scanrio with others.Thoughts:Overall, a fun game to sit down and kill a bit of free time with, but with enough to do to occupy a larger block of time if you have it to spare.  While the maps have various playfield sizes you can choose from, it is still only a single layer map (at least form what I've been able to find - I might just be missing something in the UI/game), but never felt 'small' or confined.  The NPC events (even teh bad events) tend to be fun (or at least as much impact you allow them to be, and provide a very real sense of 'Aw crap, what happened this time'.One thing I'd like to eventually see in RimWorld would be a variation of the random NPC 'story' archive you get in Dwarf Fortress.  You don't really see the characters 'story' recorded in the development of your colony/camp, and given the nature of the game, I think that could draw you in to the lives of the characters a bit more while increasing your emotional investment in them.Recommend?If you enjoy 'god' games where you do more influencing than directly control gameplay - Yes!Gameplay Livestream Recording:  


YouTube™ Video: Surprise Live Stream - Rimworld | Alpha 14 Preview 

			Views: 65		

			Feel free to drop in and to ask questions about the games on the channel, about other games in general, or if you just want to drop in a be social! ►Already a subscriber or a community regular?

content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								An astoundingly complex and deep game that suffers from a bit of early game difficulties.Please don't misunderstand me, this is one of my favourite games of the decade - before playing on Steam, I've played every Alpha adding up to hundreds of hours. If you're willing to put in some effort, the rewards of watching your little ♥♥♥♥ed up ant farm of colonists is exceptionally rewarding.But I would be remiss if I didn't point out how excruciatingly difficult it is to learn the early game of RimWorld. You start with very little (in the base version) and have to learn by constant trial and error what's necessary to survive past the first winter. "Oh, I should probably dispense nutrient paste until I have a way to easily replenish stocks. And I'll need a lot of tuques and parkas if I want to get work done during the winter. And don't skimp on cleaning and hailing, or else you'll find a lot of carcasses go to waste and people go insane from their sorry surroundings (?!)."But I suppose that's also part of its charm, if you're willing to learn the hard lessons the game teaches you.Overall, this game is worth the praise by leaps and miles, but it still needs some fine tuning.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								I never could get into Dwarf Fortress. The graphics turned me off. After all, I'm not a 14 year old living in 1983 anymore! However, I was always intrigued by the stories I read about in Dwarf Fortress.RimWorld has sufficient graphics for me to get into the stories it generates. So far, the longest any of my colonies have survived is 115 days, with its population reaching six residents at its highest. Many of my colonies start off well, rising to a pinacle of progress that then crumbles under the accumulated weight of my colonists' mental breakdowns. They end with some tragedy, such as the last survivor starving to death, his eyes gouged out by another crazed colonist who succumbed to her injuries first. Or my last colonist lies in the dark, both feet shot off by the jailbreaking raider who then returned and set everything on fire, eventually incinerating the footless colonist.If you like community-building simulations, you should try this game. If you want to play this as a straight-up colony sim, I recommend adding the mods that include fully-equipped space marines so you aren't slaughtered early on. With that said, there is something for playing the unmodded game of shipwrecked random colonists.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								I'll be honest, I'm not the biggest fan of this genre. I haven't played much dwarf fortress, games like Towns, Gnomoria and Craft The World usually elicit a single long playthrough that, though enjoyable, usually concludes my time with the game whenever I have everything unlocked.RimWorld has been pretty much the opposite. I've played about 5-6 times already, lost my colony to various things, whether it infection wiping out my people, raiders gunning down all but one of my colonists and leaving the surivor to wander around the compound with crippling depression or whatever...it doesn't matter. I just start up a new colony and go at it again.A little reccomendation: If you play games like Xcom or stuff like that with iron man off, don't do so with this game. Go in the way it's meant to be played, it's surprisingly easy to go through with restarting, and I haven't had any bugs so far. Honestly, I think the best thing this game does is remove character creation. Clicking random until you get people who generally fit what you need kinda detaches you from them, meaning that when they inevitably die, you're fine with just going again (at least for me). I still haven't had any playthroughs that I'm incredibly proud of, but so far, every loss has taught me something and I feel like I now have a really efficient method of starting thte game.One universal piece of advice: Build graves as soon as somebody on the map dies, friend or foe, and get all bodies buried ASAP. Just trust me.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								Been playing since Alpha 2, and this "early release" is much farther along and very playable, unlike many others who hit Steam.Maybe you'll build your batteries outside. When they blow up in the rain, and you watch colonists die in the fire trying to put it out, or run screaming away only to return to desolation, you'll know what you did wrong.Maybe your colonists just aren't skilled enough to farm and mine basic subsistence, and you watch them slowly go mad as they refuse to do the work necessary to survive.Maybe you got too lax with the squirrels in your camp, and one goes rabid, biting your best medic, which is the last straw for her - what with the bedroom being too small and the food being too boring - and causes a psychotic break. In her rampage, she gives your best fighters concussions, and you couldn't get anyone to subdue her before they're all bleeding, dying, and the medic is passed out in the wilderness dying of stavation.Maybe a lightning strike happens to hit the one wire connecting your turret bank, right before a bandit assault. Or angry natives bring a rocket launcher, creating a hole in your defenses that you thought were solid. You survive the attack, but the lack of preperation, injuries and death, and loss of supplies are just too much for your colony to recover from.Maybe, maybe you'll lay the foundations for a thriving trade outpost. A Deadwood in space. A Babylon 5 on a planet's surface. A spot of stability in the messy frontier of space.Whatever happens, you will learn what went wrong, what detail you missed, what you can improve for next time, as you watch your colony wrestle survival and sanity, before closing their book and opening another.Difficulty and story style options, along with previewing and rerolling your colonist(s), helps you start off into the game you want to play.

content:

Early Access Review
								This game, despite lacking a scripted campaign or story, is the most emotional, intense, and deep game I've ever played. Simply put: it is a masterpiece of emergent storytelling. There is nothing like the ups and downs you experience as your best farmer loses his arm to a stray bullet, the tension as a heat wave prevents you from building those crucial defenses, or the horror you experience when your farm catches fire just before winter hits; the joys of seeing your colony through another harsh winter, or the humor of watching a rabid squirrel try to take down a machine gun turret.I've been playing this game for years now over the course of its development and it only gets better with each update. Definite reccomend.

content:

Early Access Review
								Great game.  Be prepared to invest some time into learning the mechanics.  Sure you could read a guide, but it is more enjoyable to stumble along and have your colonists die in horrible ways.The game designers have a perverse sense of humor.  I started one colony as the only male with two nubile female colonists - one of them a former sex slave.  Just as things are starting to warm up, my man-hating, ex-wife joins the colony and becomes good friends with the other two female colonists.  In the interests of restoring harmony, I send my ex-wife out hunting for food with a knife against large carnivores.  Ex-wife's body is found by the women and dragged back to the colony causing both to go into deep depression.  Thus begins a downward spiral that ends with the colony starving and then wiped out by raiders.Great game !   Would send my ex-wife out hunting carnivores with a knife again !

								This game is perfect if you want to create your own story.I made this beautiful colony with four people in it. Everybody was doing their job, every now and then someone had a mental break down and ran around naked for a while - nothing major. But suddenly I lost control: In order to cool meat (and other food) I placed a fridge thingy in the wall, powered by my battery which is connected to the huge solar panel in the middle of the colony. It worked fine for days until suddenly the battery decided to blow up. Usually not a huge issue but the blast killed the dude sleeping next to it (he often had mental break downs so I placed his bed in the small room next to the battery).Now, because I like to live cheap I build most of my stuff with wood. Explosion + wood is not so good, as you probably know. So suddenly half my colony was burning to the ground while my other three colonists were sleeping peacefully in the only steel building I ever build.When they woke up in the morning the fire was gone - but so was my battery, solar panel, all of my supplies, workbenches and even my crops. "Thank god I still have some potatos." I thought. So I started some repairs and decided to bury that one guy who was sleeping next to the battery. The next day I get a message "Heatwave incoming.". Now, because I had no steel left from the repairs I could not build the fridge thingy again and as a result my colonists had to work at ~55°C. Didn't take long until my best dude fainted. Then the other one. Followed by the elderly lady (who is the only one in that shi t hole who knows how to plant potatoes). One after another died - my precious work of was destroyed in a matter of minutes. If that ♥♥♥♥♥♥ battery didn't blow up I could have saved everyone from the heat by putting them in my cooled storage room. But god wasn't on my side this time.Great.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								Pavel Shal, a lone Orassan female only age sixteen has accidently ejected herself from the mothership during a game of hide and seek. Looks like the children will never find her. Landing on an unknown world she is forced to endure trials as she builds her base within an old pre-industrial ruin found in the side of a rock formation by the sea. At first it was peaceful, there was nothing to fear. Traders came, she freed two men from slavery, built a barracks and a hospital as they gathered supplies. But then came the Federation Remnants - Coming crashing down through the roof of her very home and began blasting everyone. Only Pavel and Limu servived, Garry was dead, they didn't even leave a body behind. By the end of the skirmish Limu was in critical condition and one of Pavel tamed arctic wolves were killed, while Garry's body was gone. While the Federation had lost due to her using their weapons against them, they were ill prepared. Their next meeting on the battle field, may be their last.I freakin' love this game man! So many mods to play with, debugging menu is even better. Starting large raids on small settlements and trying to see if you can get them to survive. Can't even mention the Zombie mod. Thought you were done killing all those tribes men and federation officers? No, you're wrong. Here they come, screaming like wild animals!I recommond this to any friend that loves base-building, supply running, tactics and above all Survival. As long as the content grows, I believe this game will grow. Though I wish you could start a community up directly next to another already made. Starting next to a pirate base in the same region, would be hilarious. Or have a choice to expand and start multiple settlements under the name of one colony, in various regions; even invading other colonies/tribes/etc.

content:

Early Access Review
								The gameplay of Dwarf Fortress + the graphics of Prison Architect.  It's that simple.  Usually those kind of formulae are unfairly reductionist, but it fits RimWorld perfectly.  If you're one of those tortured souls who loves "winning" in DF and have been longing for a version with a slick UI and slightly-less-abstract graphics, stop reading and buy this now.  If you've never played DF but love minutiae and incredible flexibility in micromanagement as depicted by Colorforms, give this a shot.  It's less a game and more of a narrative simulator, but it's no less fun.  Everyone will die, brutally, repeatedly, and it will be fantastic.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								Rimworld is both frustrating and fascinating.  I start with the 3 colonist, and currently play on the "rough" setting.  I can't make it past 40 to 50 in-game days.... yet.  I'm challenged by raiders, man hunting animals, thunder, electrical explosions, starvation, diseases, mentally broken settlers, hypothermia, and the list goes on and on.  In addition to the threats, and perhaps a bigger challenge, the work load of each settler must be carefully balanced or I risk having too many important task ignored.Here are a few tips and things I have learned that may help a complete newbie:1) A single settler with a knife should not be hunting boar by themselves.2) Make sure you roll settlers of whom at least one has a high skill in mining, growing, cooking, and/or research.  Both cooking and crop farming require a higher skill for some production.3) You want a good miner, because I recommend choosing a mountainous area and burrowing into the rock for shelter.4) Settle near a geyser for eventual geothermal power, but for now skip the solar and just build a fuel powered generator.5) Build walls around all of your areas where power is either generated, or used.  Keep powered appliances seperate from the living areas.  When fire erupts (and it will), The walls will keep the initial explosion contained.6) Firefoam poppers- BUILD THEM.7) Be careful not to choose settlers that lack basic skills such as firefighting or dumb labor.  If you do choose one, make sure the skill you are choosing them for is worth the trade off.8) Automated turrets are great for fighting raiders, but expect that they will break down often.  9) I perfer to melee all combat situations.  Shooting is a pain right now in this game.  If you choose to use a gun or bow, you must first send the settler to stand closer to the target if you want to be accurate.10) If a potential prisoner doesn't have any skills that will signifigantly help you, don't bother capturing them..... unless you want to wait for a slave trader to come buy them.There is a lot more I could think of, but thats just a few things off the top of my head.  This game rocks, it's a lot of fun.  Buy it if you like survival and resource management, you will not regret it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								The Sims meets Minecraft in a survival setting. Gather resources, build your colony and take care of the emotional needs of your people. They will go about their daily business by themselves and have a strong personality, only following your general guidelines rather than being controlled directly by you. They might very well just lie down stargazing when you desperately need that wall built, or refuse to kill an attacking animal due to their pasifist background. You get fond of them over time, and when they die it is like watching your favorite Game of Thrones characters murdered. Managing their mood and keeping them motivated is actually the most challenging part of the game, and you will experience someone going on a psychotic rage killing everyone in your base because they did not care for your decoration or eating without a table, then that broken romance pushed them over the edge. So keep an eye out on those mood parameters, those are your real enemy.There is a lot to take into account in this game, and dangers and disasters lurks around every corner. Heat waves, fires, raids, dangerous animals, food poisoning, disease... And of cuorse you need to keep those mood stats high too, as there is a long list of things that will bring them down. Your settlers are picky and weak minded, the battle never ends. It is still a game that is under development, so I will not give too much criticism of the problems I found. I hope they will be fixed though. The most annoying issue is generally unfair deaths. The game is determined to kill your people and keeping them alive is a constant fight. That is a fun and satisfyiong battle for the most part. But sometimes, they just die of the most stupid reasons, which is super annoying. For example, a pasifist who refuse to protect himself may run away from a slow moving rat that is attacking. Then stop and wait for the rat to bite, then run again and repeat until dead. Obviously the right way for the AI to react would be to run inside and let your traps deal with your problem, or just run and not stop until the animal gave up. Since you do not control your people directly, you cannot override stupid behavior easily. You would have to trick the person into building something inside with a high priority for example, to get him away from the danger outside. But this wont always work well. Fighting a dumb AI should not be what the game is about, there are enogh other dangers to deal with.Another example is a pet I completely forgot about suddenly started to chase people around and kill them one by one. It was allowed to go inside through doors that are usually keeping enemies outside, so there was nowhere to hide. In a matter of seconds my whole colony was murdered. And I was not allowed to kill it. Probably a glitch.Having people or pets go on a psychotic rage and murder everyone gets old, and too often the ones you try to keep alive is the worst enemy. Most of the time when I lost my colony, it is due to them going insane over trivial things and killing everyone. It would be more fun if they were not a bunch of weak minded sissies who turn on you at the first opportunity, there are already a lot of other things to consider in this sim, and personally I enjoyed the other aspects more than micromanaging peoples mood to avoid them going on a killing spree.But generally, this is a interesting game that has a lot of details which will drag you in, and when you succeed it is very satisfying.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								9/10 - Here's why..There’s something more to this game than just the old - shoot that/kill that...grow that/harvest that. This game is addictive because it actually connects to the player on a personal level. Here are three examples of why.....I got raided by a bunch of pirates. I killed two of them, but the third I shot in the leg. He went down in pain, wriggling on the ground. Do I save him and nurse him back to health? Or do I execute him on the spot? .A dog wondered into my base. One of my tribe mates became fond of the dog and tamed it. It became his pet. One day the dog wondered outside the base during a pirate raid. One of the pirates shot it. After the raid it slowly died. I was unable to save it because I didn’t have the right facilities. The tribe mate who was fond of the dog became depressed and stabbed another tribesman to death..A ship crash landed near my base. The pilot of the ship wass gravely wounded, bleeding to death on the ground. Do I save him or leave him to die because I don't have enough food to feed him?.These are three of an almost unlimited amount of scenarios that can occur, that strike the player on a personal level. I really recommend this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								Rimworld. Kept hearing about this game from my friends but wasn't sure it was for me. I'd played countless hours of Dwarf Fortress over the years and I couldn't see anything this game provided that DF didn't already have.Never have I been so wrong.There's a lot of goodness in the way the game plays out. The interactions between your colonists or "pawns" as they are often referred to is deep and interesting. Like many other games, you collect resources and build with them but the similarity ends there. There's also a rich faction model and a moderately well-designed combat system. You can expect your colony to be visited by traders, raiders, orbital trade vessels, and even survivors crash-landing in escape pods who need your help to survive their injuries.The modding community is going strong, even though the game is still in early access. There's medieval mods which turn it from a pure sci-fi game (though the sci-fi is admittedly weak on laser beams and high-tech staples) to a deranged Renaissance fair gone horribly wrong. There's even a mod which puts you square in the middle of a zombie apocalypse, as if dealing with raiders, toxic fallout, and the occasional volcanic winter wasn't enough. Sounds too hard? You control the threat level by picking a "storyteller", which is a great new thing I have not seen in any game before. The difficulty level also can be changed from where it launches exploding antelopes during a solar flare that destroyed your electronics down to where free food reigns down from space in cargo pods.The game has a lot of replayability already, new mods are being added every day, and the game is STILL in early access. I'm very keen on getting my money's worth out of video games, and with the wealth of choices available today there's no reason the discerning purchaser shouldn't be. However this is one of those gems you will play a lot, particularly if you're a fan of building and colony sims ... or a Dwarf Fortress fanatic like me.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								Rimworld is just an exceptional game. Take some characters from "The Sims", choose their new homeworld, and shoot them into survival space pods across the galaxy. Once they crash down it is now up to you to manage their daily lives. Some will be better assigned as a hunter/gatherer, and at times, a soldier. Others are your doctors, harvesters, crafters, cooks, farmers, and ranchers. How you go about assigning tasks to these people depends on the needs of the basecamp and the capacity of your community.Some days you may have a disgruntal citizen as he just got dumped by his fellow survivor, had to then sleep on the floor during a heatwave since there was a lack of proper beds and now has contracted an infection because the injury sustained while hunting a "Muffalo" never got treated in a sterile environment. Now he may die from the infection. Oh, and his dog died yesterday. Hero to zero in one day. Of course you don't want to lose this survivor as he is the only one skilled with ranged weapons for protection and the raiders are due for an attack soon. So you re-prioritize the day to have the survivor who dumped the guy provide treatment with the medical supplies you purchased from a roaming trade caravan the day before. Luckily when you setup your game you rolled a sweet doc and the infection gets resolved.    Each one of your survivors has a random skill set, relationships with others, past medical history, and postive and negative traits. All of this comes with random rolls when first setting up a game. You can custom any part of the game, from starting technologies, amount of people to start with, materials at your disposal. Everything is customizable and worlds are procedural. Replayability ++.  This game is for those who like managing resource gathering and base building, balancing social and personal needs, and simply combat.  The development is on going and very active so you may need to lose a save game from time to time but ultimately I've found no issue starting over and trying new strategies; Rimworld is that good of a game.  After all, its a whole new game each time. It's a buy.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								Ignore my hours in-game, I've had this since around Alpha 5 or 6. However with it now being on Steam, this game needs as many great reviews as possible given how much time, effort, and heart Tynan Sylvester has put into it. I'm not one to write reviews often. I think I have written a total of at most 3 out of my 150+ library, but this game above all others really deserves it. So few games have balanced so many game genres in such an addictive and entertaining way. I've purchased multiple copies of this for friends simply because I can't recommend it enough to anyone who enjoys sandbox, survival, strategy, drama, almost any genre of game. And the modding community (and the support they get) is just as fantastic, along with the community itself. Everyone who plays this always has a few great stories of misery or triumph to walk away with, and then come back for another 4 month binge. Tynan Sylvester has truly made one of the finest games of this generation, and the only real issue I see with it is what little coverage it seems to get. Now that it's on Steam though, hopefully that'll change.10/10, would cannabalize again. Well done, Tynan.

								I've never actually posted a review in Steam, and I've never played a game like Rimworld. By that I mean top down view, that and side scrollers just aren't my style. I was even nervous purchasing it. Then I realized I will never regret it. This game s amazing, the stories that come up just from normal gameplay are amazing. My pig farm, was struck by lightning, most of the herd was killed instantly, the fences caught on fire, and my house almost went with it. I sat there in amazement that my entire heard just died from a freak accident in less than a second, as my colonists enjoyed their last pork dinners for a long while. The complexity of Rimworld is extremely deep, the basics are easy to pick up, and the story of what happens to your people will be unparalleled.

Early Access Review
								I had been meaning to play Rimworld for awhile but never got a chance. A press key gave me the push to dive into the game I needed and man am I happy to have taken the plunge. While I might not have the experiance of veterans of the series, I still had a blast playing the game. I did a ~1 hour initial impressions of the alpha 14 version if you want to see it in action: 


YouTube™ Video: Pinstar Plays Rimworld 

			Views: 881		

			Rimworld is a game about survival, adaptation and management where you take control of a colony on a distant world and try to survive against the odds.		

It has a fairly steep learning curve, but not nearly as steep as, say Dwarf Fortress. Playing through the early newbie stages is worth the time and effort to learn the game as it is a deep, rich and fun game full of emergent storytelling and gameplay. Highly reccomend this title and would pay full price for it even if the Devs didn't give me a press key.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								I was reluctant to buy this game, being an Early Access game with simple graphics and a hefty price, but i'm so glad i changed my mind.Trying to explain what the game is really hard, due to all mechanics it have, so i'll focus on what i would want to know:This game is what I've been wanting to play my whole life and didn't knew, this is the beautiful son of Dwarf Fortress and The sims, in a very awesome way.The mechanics are deep,but not drag the game down, the learning curve is sometimes brutal, but lovely, the colonist have a lot of "personality" and the most memorable stories are created by how faulty they are, as i said, think of dwarf fortress but focusing more in your dworfs as single beings. Also, while this is an Early access game,this development is more like a Don't Starve EA, the updates are very "feature complete", you won't get a bunch of features that don't work or need a lot of balancing, you get one or two per version, but they are solid, tested and pretty much bug free, with a  few hotfixes solving the problems, this make the game looks like a complete game that is always evolving.The updates come in a steady way, 2 or 3 months per big update.The modding community is healthy and very active, the developer is very present in both the official forums and in the Reddit subreddit, implementing some suggestions and ignoring the ones that didn't fit the game.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								I started out with 3 ship survivors. Spider, my chef and construction worker, Lumi, my hunter, and Carry, my paramedic. A monkey names Angus also came with them. Life was good for a time. Everyone was happy, a raid came from time to time with little to no affect on colony. A nurse called Dawson comes, who hates violence. Another adventurer comes, (can't remember his name, we'll just call him Bill) being chased by pirates. I fight them off easily with no casualties on my side. Bill, it turns out, was not worth it. He was totally worthless in everything. But that didn't matter, I already had a colony with 4 good pawns and a monkey, so I was good.Boy was I wrong.Eventually a raid comes, with 3 pirates. But what is one of them holding? What do I spy in one of their hands? A mother ♥♥♥♥ing molotov. I sent 4 of my pawns to stand ready to go and fight them (Dawson was just doing his own thing). We kill 2 of  the pirates before they know what hit them, but who survives? The mother ♥♥♥♥ing guy with the molotovs. He snuck up behind Bill and set fire to everything. Bill was set on fire, Dawson too, all of my colonists were set in flames. Molotov man decides this is enough and heads off. Carney stops, drops and rolls and rescues everyone but Lumi and Argus, who go with the flames. All because of motha♥♥♥♥♥♥♥Bill. But fate decided "Ya know what, lets just keep being a ♥♥♥♥♥ to this guy" so another pirate raid comes by. Luckily with no molotovs. Spider, who is bedridden, also decides to go insane at this time and to eat anyone she sees. The fight was intense, but we won in the end, and are still thriving.But pirates burned my god damn monkey.11/10 would hate Bill again.

Early Access Review
								When I saw this game for the first time, I was like "How the f**k this game has 10/10 ratings on steam with over 4,5k votes". I decided then, to download an illegal, pirate version of the game (yes, I commited a crime!) to check it out, because I thought it's impossible for this game to be worth 30$. Boooy, I was so wrong! I've spent over 8 hours straight playing old pirate version of that game, I've started my colonies several time, and everytime my colonies died, instead of being angry at the game, I was even more motivated to start over again from the beggining to create another "unperfect" colony that will die sooner or later. On the next day, I went to work and I was thinking about this game much more often, than I think about sex (and I do think about sex a LOT!). I came back from work, and I immidiately bought this game from Ludeon site, registered it on steam and started another 8-hour game session, leaving my naked girlfriend alone in bed...Conclusion: This game has stolen my life, it's by far best game I've played in 2016, it has literally unlimited potential and It's definitely worth 30$. I recommended this game to few of my friends at work, they've played pirate versions as demos, and on the next day they've also bought this game. So, if you're not convinced by the old school graphics, download older version, and If you like it, show some appreciation for developers and buy this game, because it's get better with every update!.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								9/10 - Here's why..There’s something more to this game than just the old - shoot that/kill that...grow that/harvest that. This game is addictive because it actually connects to the player on a personal level. Here are three examples of why.....I got raided by a bunch of pirates. I killed two of them, but the third I shot in the leg. He went down in pain, wriggling on the ground. Do I save him and nurse him back to health? Or do I execute him on the spot? .A dog wondered into my base. One of my tribe mates became fond of the dog and tamed it. It became his pet. One day the dog wondered outside the base during a pirate raid. One of the pirates shot it. After the raid it slowly died. I was unable to save it because I didn’t have the right facilities. The tribe mate who was fond of the dog became depressed and stabbed another tribesman to death..A ship crash landed near my base. The pilot of the ship wass gravely wounded, bleeding to death on the ground. Do I save him or leave him to die because I don't have enough food to feed him?.These are three of an almost unlimited amount of scenarios that can occur, that strike the player on a personal level. I really recommend this game.
