			Feel free to drop in and to ask questions about the games on the channel, about other games in general, or if you just want to drop in a be social! ►Already a subscriber or a community regular?

content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								An astoundingly complex and deep game that suffers from a bit of early game difficulties.Please don't misunderstand me, this is one of my favourite games of the decade - before playing on Steam, I've played every Alpha adding up to hundreds of hours. If you're willing to put in some effort, the rewards of watching your little ♥♥♥♥ed up ant farm of colonists is exceptionally rewarding.But I would be remiss if I didn't point out how excruciatingly difficult it is to learn the early game of RimWorld. You start with very little (in the base version) and have to learn by constant trial and error what's necessary to survive past the first winter. "Oh, I should probably dispense nutrient paste until I have a way to easily replenish stocks. And I'll need a lot of tuques and parkas if I want to get work done during the winter. And don't skimp on cleaning and hailing, or else you'll find a lot of carcasses go to waste and people go insane from their sorry surroundings (?!)."But I suppose that's also part of its charm, if you're willing to learn the hard lessons the game teaches you.Overall, this game is worth the praise by leaps and miles, but it still needs some fine tuning.

content:
Posted: October 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								One of the best early access games I've ever played. This game has kept my attention for over 140 hours so far, and I plan on sinking a lot more into it. Absolutely addicting and well worth the price. There are so many different ways this game can play out due to the variation of colonist skills and personalities, game type, starting biome, and a bunch of other things. The mods are top notch and the community are very helpful. A small story from my game: Decided to accept a pyromaniac with a very low breaking point and no skills to speak of into my colony - spent a while basically guarding her whilst she kept starting fires around my home place. After a while, I felt I had enough of her and locked her in a room with utterly nothing to her name (I had even taken the clothes off her back) and let her starve to death. I forgot to look at the colonist relationship screen before I did this. Turns out, she was the daughter of one of my hard-working colonists. The mother falls into a deep depression and can barely do any work before she breaks and binges on beer. She passes out and wakes up with a mammoth hangover, thus making her mood worse and breaking again. It decended into a vicious cycle, and I could no longer keep beer in my stockpile. The mother eventually recovered somewhat... but I didn't. I felt utterly awful, and now I try not to take in people who are mental and/or have a severe lack of skills, and check the relationships tab before I... uh.. "let go" of colonists.10/10, will be playing for at least another 140 hours.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								Currently at 170 hours.I only play Permadeath (no saves except on exit), Classic Storyteller, Some Challenge difficulty, Crashlanded Scenario (3 colonists basic scenario) and I accept every random choice they make for me (planet seed, starting location, colonist stats, etc) no matter how good or bad. This playstyle has given me so many wildly different narratives, stories of triumph, defeat, sadness, and unexpected joy. This is a game about the journey, not the finish line.I still have not had a successful colony to date. My most successful one lasted probably about 30-40 gameplay hours, which ultimately fell to an unchecked infestation while dealing with attrition and a seige. I sat in silence, respectfully released all my animals, and watched in abject detatchment as my legless prisoner eventually succumbed to simultaneous starvation and infection. He died alone, in extreme pain, and surrounded by the clattering claws of murderous bugs scraping his cell walls. I like to think his slip into unconciousness saved him from the horrific fate that awaited.The game looks basic, but the interactions between everything are masterfully crafted. You will find yourself having to make hard choices that will really make you question your own values in life. The AI is a masterful story-teller.I can't express this enough: the real enjoyment from this game comes from the meta story. It's a great colony builder, and you can micro-manage so much that it will really satisfy those OCD control issues, but you have to learn to accept losses. It's all about risk management, time management, and resource management. One of the most stressful, but satisfying gameplay experiences I've had in a long time.My only advice: learn to accept losses and failure.

Early Access Review
								Dwarf Fortress was a game I played a few years back, and one I would like to play again when it 'eventually' gets closer to completion. RimWorld helps to scratch that itch of managing a colony though, and it does it well. As of this review, I have been playing the game during Alpha 15. I can safely say that this is an excellent game that I've poured several hours already without fully mastering all RimWorld's content.For what its worth, RimWorld is a fantastic game in the colony builder genre. Compared to Dwarf Fortress it perhaps dumbs down some things - like having you mine steel out of walls instead of mining iron and working it into steel first. However if you can get past some of the simplification there is still quite a bit of depth in the game. There is a still caring and managing of your different colonists through assigning them all different work tasks and ensuring they are fed and happy; and while you probably won't have failure due to tantrum spirals, you still have to watch out for the safety of your colonists - be it from dangerous predators, roving raiders, infectious diseases, and rather 'fickle' weather.Something to bring up as well is that if you are coming from Dwarf Fortress, or just picking up a colony builder game for the first time, you won't be spending a whole lot of time trying to figure out how to play. The game features a very basic tutorial - and even without the tutorial the game has a sweet user interface which makes it very easy to actually sit down and just play the game.I certainly encourage buying this game, even in Early Access. It does indeed play quite well without much in the ways of irritating bugs, and the developer seems quite busy in continuing to add new content to the game as well. Check It Out.

Posted: July 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								I used to play rimworld before it came out on steam, since a very early alpha i believe. When i was browsing the steam community, and saw a rimworld review, i immediately dashed to my PC, and got busy working on obtaining the steam key.It was a little drama obtaining the steam key due to the huge amount of traffic on the devs' servers, and i found myself frustrated a couple of times, but after a long time of doing, i finally got it. This wont affect my review though.Rimworld is an extraordinary colony management sim, which combines PA and dwarf fortress. The game is frequently updated (credits to u ty), and such theres something to explore most of the time.As mentioned in the huge list below, rimworld is a sci-fi, albeit realistically aimed simulator, and succesfully lives up to type with the amount of features it haves. The features all together make it very realistic-like, but thats not the end. The devs will continue on this game for a while (hopefully), and new features will arise.In any case, this really is a recommender, since its lives up to the features it promises, unlike the big AAA games everyone talks about.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								Incredible game. At times it's survival drama where you lose days to sickness, lose animals to predators, limbs to explosions and your companions to attacking tribes. At other times survival horror, executing prisoners while sealing off excavated caves filled with ancient dangers who want to end your time on their Rimworld. Then sometimes it's survival fun, everything is working, your crops are growing and the five people who tried to raid you are lying naked in your courtyard while you consider whether or not to feed them to your pack of Yorkshire terriers or harvest their organs to sell to orbital traders.Menu heavy, and slight learning curve. However the narratives that play out everytime among my survivors in this alpha game are amazing and at times rival AAA storytelling.Randomly generated everything means tons of content and reasons to build another base and keep trying.Perma death is a nice option, and my preferred playstyle. But there is always the option to not turn it on.

content:
Posted: April 6
Early Access Review
								I've played this game for quite a while, and i've loved every minute of it. What really impresses me with this game is it's attention to detail. For the ability to tell what each room you built is used for and labling it as such, to the description of the artwork your mooks create that's based on real game events. Plus the ability for shananagins is pretty good too. You built a stripe mine and it's now full of deadly bugs now? crank those heaters up to 11 and wait for the bugs to pass out from heat stroke then light their lairs on fire. Then watch in horror as the fire spreads to your base and you pray your fire suppresion devices are placed in a good enough possition to stop the damage. not to mention that the sound track is awesome.Hands down the BEST early access game i've ever played.

Early Access Review
								I broke my personal rule about not buying early access games to get RimWorld, and very glad I did.Zero crashes, and not noticed any bugs in first ~50 hours playing (and many long nights!), far more polished than most final released games.One of the overall top rated games on Steam for very good reasons - intuitive interface, easy to get started, lots of fun surprises. At the easiest level its pretty much a sandbox to build your favorite base, but anything harder than the easiest setting it becomes quite challenging to survive all the surprises and can snowball quite quickly into a disaster.I'm too wimpy to survive the harder difficulty settings yet!

content:
Posted: October 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								3 survivors crash landed on an uncharted planet. Among these survivors was a man named Hudson, and his pet cat, Groucho. Hudson was very antisocial, and spent most of his time in solitude with Groucho. after 2 weeks, something horrible happened. A rapid bunny attacked Hudson, breaking both of his legs and giving him a slight infection. Hudson spent the next few weeks in his bed, being unable to walk. The entire time, Groucho was right there in his room, never leaving his side. Unfortunately, his condition only got worse, despite the doctor's best efforts. After using most of their food and medical supplies trying to heal Hudson, with no progress, the remaining survivors made the difficult decision to put Hudson out of his misery. As the doctor carved into Hudsons, chest with a rusty knife, Groucho, Hudson's beloved companion, snapped and killed the doctor in a matter of seconds. After eating part of the body, Groucho went after the other survivors, killing them with ease. In a matter of minutes, an entire colony was wiped out by one housecat with a thirst for vengance.      10/10

Early Access Review
								- Have three characters in start, one is named Biscuit Holmes, and a dog - Biscuit Holmes has a wife but sadly she didn't travel with him in the escape pods- Dog decides to be trained by Biscuit Holmes and eventually he becomes the owner- Biscuit Holmes and the two other survivors decide to form a bond and become great friends- All is well, and to make it better: One day a new survivor joined my colony, the United Rice Fields of Africa- That one survivor was Biscuit Holmes's wife- I create a bed for them since they need their business (insert Lenny face)- Manage to fight off raids and the colony expands and grows- One day a special raid occurs, this time they used frag grandes- Me not knowing, send Biscuit Holmes and his dog to fight them off- Don't focus on the enemies and it's too late because I hear an explosion go off- Look where Biscuit Holmes is and notice that his dog has died in the explosion- Another enemy charges, Biscuit Holmes kills him- Another explosion goes off, Biscuit Holmes dies in it- Have another survivor named Echo fight off the last raider- Biscuit Holmes and his dog's body lay on the cold floor with a dead raider next to them- Mrs. Holmes doesn't realize what happens - She finds out and gets saddened and depressed- Colony has lost two important people- Next few days, Ms. Holmes gets an infection- Send her to a medical bed to be treated and hope she lives- She dies in her sleep, and is buried with her husband and his dogThis is all a true story, and this game has done so many things to me to play with my feels. I recommened this game to anyone who wants a good management game that's based on important choices and survival. I have screenshots on my profile showing their graves if those are wondering.10/10

content:
Posted: October 25, 2016
Early Access Review
									Definitely a quirky little game.  The first 5 times i looked at the screenshots for this game I had a little trouble believing it could be engaging.  You read that right, 5 times, if not more, because it would continually show up on my recommendations list.  I would scrutinize the screenshots in complete disbelief.  Would these little larva like bobble things elicit the kind of excitement one feels for a game that keeps them coming back the way armor sets in WOW keep people paying a monthly fee?  Obviously i was skeptical.  As it is with many things in life the only real decision can be made once you have a little skin in the game.  So i bought it. Discounted.  I'm a sucker for pretty faces and getting' something for a little less than I could have a week ago.	Because bullet points are basically the end-all be-all of human existence, here is my bulleted list of impressions of this game.  NOTE: 27 hours of beer infused, "to hell with my week end obligations", playing at the time of this writing.- Limited tech tree, in the sense that it doesn't really go anywhere.  Escalation is not game depth.  Admittedly I've not fully dug deep into this tech tree, but you kind of intuit it after about hour 16.  Well it took me that long at least.  I'm a slow learner.  Still, there are neat little surprises that a lot of games fail to deliver.  Like a television?  It took me two weeks to carve a sculpture out of stone but i had a T.V. in a day or two.  What the F are they watching?  It could not have been good, as evidenced by the depression that set in pretty quickly for the prisoners i had been feeding the flesh of their fallen compatriots.  Ok, maybe no amount of T.V. was gonna keep morale up under those circumstances.- YOU CAN EAT PEOPLE!!!!! So cool.  And along those lines your peeps will get bummed out if there are too many corpses around.  Somehow this sweet and sour contrast is heartening, but also provides an interesting kind of challenge that i haven't seen in a measurable degree in other games i've played.  Your little dudes get wigged out but stuff that happens in the game.  "Bob, I'm really sorry bandits killed you pet llama.  We'll make them eat their friends.  Promise."  It definitely endears you to the game and draws you closer to the little, pistol carrying, sometimes drug and alcohol abusing, larva people you're managing.  Or not managing.  The AI let's you do more or less or less or more or a little less then a lot more. You can manage and prioritize where and what they do, much like the SIMs but you can't control how they feel about it.  The little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, regardless of what you do will sometimes just flip each other off.  BTW, bob hates ninja7.  I had nothing to do with that.  I just needed a wall built.- You can't explore other areas even though when a new game starts, a huge map is generated.  It's not clear to a new player what the relevance is of this giant game map is meant to communicate other than, "Look.  You can go to all these cool places." Nope.  This is, BTW the complete same level of disappointment experienced by "No Man's Sky" players except the reasons are completely inverted.  If you play "No Man's Sky" you'll know what I mean.- The great beaver attack of 2016.  "Bob, the colony recognises your service.  You sir are a hero.  You lost your nose, and toes.  You now walk with a limp and are a bit slower on the draw then you used to be, but, we promise, when the deer run out, and the turkeys and the crops have iced over, we will eat you last."  Yes beavers started eating all of the trees in the area.  The colony depended on the lumber from those trees.  I as the leader of the colony had to make the hard decision.  With a  heavy heart, making sure i had a recent saved game, I sent out my finest larva people, armed to the teeth, and <snuffle> ... I'm sorry, it's still very hard to talk about, we lost two.  Once engaged, their true evil was unleashed.  Belligerent, rabid, hungry for wood and human flesh.  <snuffle>, this is very difficult, neither Bob or our colony will ever be the same.	In conclusion, lot's of weird stuff can go wrong in this game, and that I guess is it's big sell and real home run.  It's not an expansive game but it's deep in it's own way.  I referred to the SIMs and I think that's a really good comparison.  A little RTS on a very small scale, a little RPG and a little SIMs.  Overall for it's scope I think this is a pretty fun game.  Definitely more fun and engaging than my initial impressions of the screen shots would have led me to believe or expect.  I can only imagine this game expanding it's scope and becoming truly all encompassing.  The mechanics are solid, UI is crude but 100% what you need for this kind of management style game, and the AI nuances make it, on a small scale as engaging as a well written and heavily scripted game like Baldur's gate.  Pretty amazing for a game that relies so much on AI.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								(Note: Don't let the play time fool you. I, like many others, play the non-steam version. I have tons of hours of gametime.)This game is amazing. I've played others like it - Dwarf Fortress, Gnomoria, Towns, Timber & Stone, and others, and they all pale in comparison. (Ok, Dwarf Fortress has more complexity, but, honestly, who could every play it with the horrible interface?)It's similar to other colony-management games, but much more interesting. The basic premise is that your people crashland on sparsely-habited planet on a rim world, and have to survive, and eventually build a spaceship to escape. (The new scenario editor opens up other options, but this is the premise of the basic game.) You will battle hunger, disease, injury, hostile enemies, random events, and even interpersonal relationships.The game features three different 'storytellers' which control how often events occur and how dangerous they can be. You can play a relatively safe colony-building game, or a 'This planet hates me' game. It's your choice.The interface works well, and while there is a bit of a learning curve, it's part of the fun, and the game never gets tedious or overly complex.Features:Colonists with different skills and quirks. (Nudist artistic cannibals? You bet!)ResearchFriendly villages and traders that you can barter goods withEnemies in the form of villagers, pirates, mechanoids, giant bugs, and rabid animals.Farming and goods production that is easy to automate.Well-modelled injury and disease system, including limb loss.You can capture enemies and convince them to join your colony, or sell them into slavery.Prosthetics and organ transplants. (Yes, you can harvest a lung from a prisoner.)Tons of different animals, all of which can be tamed and trained.Several different biomes to choose from (forest, jungle, tundra, desert, ice). Each presents its own challenges.Colonist have a mood rating which is affected by many different things, including hunger, temperature, joy (fun), pain, etc. A colonist that has too low of a mood can actually go berserk.Lots of random events that keep things interesting.Cons:Some people may not care for the art style, but I love it. Similar to prison architect.Only one level (i.e., you can't dig down.) You can mine into the sides of mountains, which carries its own benefits and risks.Winning the game is a bit anti-climatic, being nothing but a short blurb, but this may get addressed in the future. Remeber, it's still early access.The best thing about this game is the stories it generates, just through normal gameplay. Some of my favorite game moments:Having everyone in my first game die of disease except for one lone person, who went berserk and lost a melee fight with an alpha-beaver. Watching a thrumbo (really big animal) wander into the middle of a firefight between me and pirates. It took a hit, got mad, and killed all of us.Having half of my colony die from heatstroke when a solar eclipse knocked out my power during a heat wave.Watching my colonist feed a dead raider to my dog who was injured in the fight with the raider. (Karma)Harvesting a lung from a captured raider to replace the one that was destroyed in my colonist by that raider. (More Karma)Having an entire herd of boomalopes die from their own explosions because one of them suffered a fatal heart attack in the middle of the night. (Boomalopes explode when they die.)Watching two of my people get into a fistfight over an insult, and have to spend time in the infirmary together afterwards.Recently, having one of my people go berserk and attack a group of visitors from a friendly tribe. They and their four panthers killed four of my six colonists before leaving.I really can't recommend this game enough. Go buy it.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								>Buys game>Starts a new game with the three survivors>First one named Glenn. He was our muscle, so he hauled stuff around and used a pistol>Second one is Dan. He was our sheriff and sharpshooter>Third one was named Min. She was in love with Dan and was our planter and miner.>First day they build house and beds. >Second day we find uranium.>Third day we found a crashed pod with a dying person in it named Gert.>Girt was our slave until the next day when she joined us.>All is good when potatos are harvested and everyone has a party.>We name our settlement New Moscow>Dan purposed to Min and she said yes. >Wedding hall is made in a ruined old granite house.>A wanderer joins us named Lyra. She was useless.>Foggy rain the next day>A wild animal raids us... But what?>It is a rhino!>Dan and Glenn set up defences in the sandbags only armed with a pistol and rife. >Others are hiding>The rhino charges Glenn as he fires pointlessly.>His head was torn off by the horn.>Dan retreats into house leading rhino to where the pet and the hiding people are.>Dan is bloodied while the others (Not including Lyra) Stabbed the rhino to death>Death part was not true.>Another person bloodied. This time it was Min.>Lyra was also bloodied by the tusk into the chest.>Gert quickly grabs the pistol and fires at the rhino as a last ditch attempt to live.>The rhino falls down.>She stabs it to death with a shiv.>A grave is made for Glenn while the others are in critical condition.>Dan recieved a peg leg after they realised he lost one.>Lyra expires next morning. Another hole in the ground. > Battery explodes.>Everyone tries to take out the flames >The hospitol burns down with patients inside.>Dan goes insane and runs away.>Gert dies from a raider attack soon after the fire stopped12/10 Best rhino killing, Peg leg pirate, Widow making game everThe god emperor approves this one.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								I rarely find a game that is a 10/10 but this game is it.One of the most robust, detailed and complex colony management games I've ever played. (never played Dwarf Fortress) You can build and design your colony a thousand different ways and still never find that 'perfect' build that can deal with everything thrown at you. I love this aspect, as it keeps me coming back for more. I often, when I'm not playing, find myself constantly thinking of new ways to tweak my colony.On top of all this, the modding community is fantastic and adds so much more to what is already there. Then tack on a fantastic development team and you easily have a 10/10 game.Worth twice the price in my book. Buy it!

content:
Posted: July 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've played since Alpha 12, this game is superb.If you don't like micro management this isn't for you, this game has such depth and a good UI that almost everything can be done.Dwarf Fortress meets Firefly in this lovely game. This is more upbeat than Prison Architect which I found a bit heavy by nature of its setting. That doesn't mean its easy, there will be Dwarf Fortress levels of 'Fun' involved.The music is perfect, even the gap between tracks is perfect, the art style is endearing and easy on the eye. Being easy on the eye is important because you'll be playing this a LOT!The story teller difficult settings are wonderful, gaming industry as a whole please take note.The modding scene is fantastic.The game is very stable, even after mods! :OThis is an Alpha and its so incredibly polished!? why can't all devs be like this?The steam key for early alpha players came as a surprise. <3Things this game could improve on? a couple of UI issues maybe, that I can't remember off the top of my head they are so minor. Possibly adding vertical levels... but part of the joy of this game is its accessibility compared to Dwarf Fortress, z-levels might hinder that.10/10Just buy it already.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								I really dont know what more I can say about RimWorld other than AMAZING.Now I do not want this to become your average review explaining how the mechanics are great and all that♥♥♥♥♥♥however, what I did think was that I would tell you a story about the game and how it came to its modern stage. RimWorld started out as a game that was literally just "A Survival Game by the Guys That Made Prison Architect" The Game". I played the game in beta and absolutely loved the simplicity of it. However, I wanted more of a challenge and from the looks of it so did the rest of the beta-community. We continue to play until a week after about 20-30 posts were made about how we wanted a challenge and they said "here, have this so more complicated stuff is added". Just like that I knew the game was heading in the right direction and dont let my hours in Steam fool you, i easily have HUNDREDS of hours on the non-steam versions (I just dont want to lose my save haha) but I would reccomend this game to anyone that likes games ranging from RUST all the way to games such as HOI4 and CIV. It does have a learning curve for example you can get in and depending on the save you can be fine and never have to worry about  athing unitl you are ready. Or you can sleep in a cave one night and get attacked by a bunch of rabid man-eating turtles while your dog goes crazy and chews off your mother's leg, so in response you kill your dog and your mother gets angry at you because you "killed her innocent dog".  It is the idea that you are never safe in the RimWorld and everything that can go wrong, may end up going wrong. You need to refrigerate food, hunt, and chose how people live and how simple things such as love life in their world can impact the rest of the tribe. A perfect mixture of adventure, RPG, strategy, and casual gaming. Constant updates and an amazing modding community the game is one of the best games that I have ever played and I know that I will continue to play it in the future as I still play Prison Architect today.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2016
Early Access Review
Overview: Rimworld is a prison architect esk game with matching art and design concepts, but with a ♥♥♥♥ tone more gameplay elements and game mechanics....What makes Rimworld stand out from the crowd is the sheer amount of customization before actually starting your save and during your time through the game. When making a new save (Starting a new colony) you can choose between a huge amount of options which will in return determine how easy, hard, balanced, fun, boring, interesting, dull, your overall game will be.To list a few things:Traits, stat multipliers, in game events, starting items, researched projects, starting location, AID (artificial intelligence director), amount of people you begin with, type of settlement, time of year, size of overall explorable map, and much-much-much more.....One of the biggest selling points of Rimworld is the "artificial intelligence director". There are 3 AID's to choose from, the carefully-paced Cassandra Classic, the slower-paced, building-oriented Phoebe Chillax, and the totally unpredictable Randy Random.Each AID will oversee your game and will make choices based on your performance, like when to start a random event, type of weather, severity of each raid, overall mood of NPC's, and yet again... Much-much-much more.On top of the AID's themselves, you may also choose the play style of them too. (Basically difficulty of each AID) Pro's: Very addictive. I've not stopped playing since I got this game. I even skipped my doctors appointment today and told them I'll be there tomorrow instead. - I waited 2 weeks for this appointment. Unique and well throughout characterized artificial intelligence directors which really do spice up the game andkeep it interesting each new save.Lovely looking art concept which fits the theme of "Rimworld" and the type of game. Massive customization Mods!Con's:Heatwaves are basically GG. The only way I found to counter them if you haven't got coolers and electric is to strip all NPC's of their clothes and turn on Dev console, then force a thunderstorm which only slighty reduces the heat.Even with the above I still normally failed to counter it and all NPC's died. (Please ♥♥♥♥ing fix this♥♥♥♥♥♥dev's, we beg of you.)Thing's go from bad, to worse, to hell real ♥♥♥♥ing quick here in Rimworld.    With my latest Tribe I was around one hour in and suddenly a psychic drone (Some really bad thing off the map which you have no control over) started to make all my people unhappy extremely badly.  10 mins later it crashes to the ground and lands on all my crops, completely wipping out all my food, then begins to freeze the land stopping my from growing anything, to which I'm given a message that  I must attack and destory it before it freezes the land more + makes everyone even more unhappy.     I tell my people to attack it when suddely 3 "AI" climb out with lazers & shields and begin attacking my 4 tribes men with clubs.  2 die instantly, and then third goes mental and begins attacking the forth. Only for the AI to then make all animals go mental and begin attacking everything else alive. Oh and a thunderstorm struck lightning too, burning what was left of my village and surrounding forest.This kind of♥♥♥♥♥♥happened in every save of my so far, but not quite of that scale tho the above is a true story. The base game lacks content.... Kinda. For the amount of time it's been out and for a price tag of £20 there is a lack of  (At least early game) content. Tribe/Colony managementis quite awful. I'd say learn Crusader kings 2 is easier then dealing with your ♥♥♥♥ing people. Lacks basic simple features  which are not game breaking but is a basic concept and should be already implemented.Conclusion: To answer the question you'll all asking.... Yes... It is worth £20.In time this game will be 100x better then it's current state ( Which is already at a high standard )

content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								I love this game so much I'm going to write my first review on it.Lag: There was no framedrops through the entire game and I played on large maps and had a 10v10 + allies&animals battle. It's like a mix of Dwarf Fortress and Towns with it's own twist. They do a really good job of achieving what you want to do, for example: you can have prioritized storages, so they will fill up one storage before the other, there is a storage for specifics so you can have stuff you want to feed animals in 1 place, and food for you people in the other. You can prioritize each individuals work from 1-4 (with empty being not worked). This allows for optimization of their skills and jobs.The most brutal and realistic part is the vitals+combat (and is my favorite). When in firefights your colonists can take cover behind trees, walls, rubble, and pretty much anything that can block a bullet. If one of your colonists get injured, most likely it can be healed, but there is the chance they lose limbs or organs from the fight (damaged beyond repair). Better medicine can lead to better healing (as well as the doctor's skill). Colonists have a large list of vital signs that need to be monitored including, but not limited to: blood filtration, blood level, consciousness, sight, hearing, moving, eating, etc. Losing organs or body parts can lower these, and getting injured and not patching up can lead your colonist to bleed to the point where they pass out and eventually die. Every organism in the game has this vital recognition, everything from a mechanoid to a squirrel.On top of all of this survial realism pazzaz, there is tons of story to be told. Like the story of the 5 townspeople plagued by the 2 months of Volcanic Winter only to be followed by 2 weeks of Toxic Fallout (probably the ash). Not only did all of the plants and animals die, but we had to eat all of the barn animals. Sadly though, while out to retrieve the barn animals, one of our people developed dementia, and two developed Carcinoma. After they were gone, starvation started to sit in again, so we prayed in the Rec room. Right as we thought it was all over the toxic fallout ended, and a trade caravan from "Patience's Cliff" (an outlander town) came, we bought all the food we could to last us. Animals almost immediately started flooding back into the area along with the regrowing grass. We continued farming and restocked our freezer. We recovered mostly, but the 2 people with Carcinoma still have it (one is stable, the other has recession), and the person with dementia still has it, all they do is walk around cleaning, and then forgetting what they're doing and wander around aimlessly. A good thing that came of this though, the 2 people with Carcinoma got married.The one con I have with this game so far:The world map is only useful for choosing where you want to settle. It would be really cool if you can use that Pemmican (preserved food), and go travel to other faction areas (like the ones that are near you via Comms Console), nefarious deeds, or friendly negotiation would be up to you. (But seriously I would love to raid those people that tried to sell me human leather, and released a pack of manhunting muffalo [long story])In conclusion: If you're in to rather difficult strategy survival games, this is the game for you.WARNING: If you don't like a challenge don't buy this game, it gets really boring with no events and the events are BRUTAL (mostly)

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14
Early Access Review
								To anybody who is reading this, it will be a long review. I will try to focus on both good and bad things (also "neutral" ones). Since this game costs quite a lot and doesn't have best graphics or any demo, it might be hard to know what is really behind this Early Access Game. My review is based on both positive, negative reviews and especially on my own experience in the game. Don't mind my relatively low play-time, I have also watched hours of gameplay and was able to see main issues (which were confirmed when I played by myself too). And yeah, I will try to keep it spoiler-free. So, let's start with positive points:+ Addictive and fun. The game can easily get an award of "Let me play 5 more minutes". There is a lot to do in this game (since it is a sandbox), which makes it a lot of fun. RimWorld can be very addictive, because you always want to do 1 more thing, before going to sleep/work etc. I personally always want to come back to my colony, to do one more thing.+ Low amount of bugs. Without mods, this game is pretty stable. I didn't have any issues and didn't encounter any game-breaking bugs. Small bugs exist, but they exist in any game.+ Optimization. I played the game on Windows PC, which can run heavy games (such as Crysis 3). So RimWorld had high fps. However, after trying this game on Mac (small Mac, without a good videocard or cooling system), I found out that it runs pretty smooth. It is not 60 fps, but my Mac didn't overheat, even without charging. If I zoomed out, the game started to have lower fps, but in general, it was possible to get 30 fps no problem.+ Depth. The game is pretty deep. I was heavily surprised by the health system alone. There are many parts of the body, which can be damaged (legs, arms, torso, head, eyes, ears, mouth/jaw, fingers/toes, heart, lungs, liver and some more). Each of them can be damaged individually (during combat) and most of them can have different diseases and problems (infections, cataracts, hearing loss, scars, heart-pumping problems, asthma etc.). On top of that, there are many different random diseases, both lethal (such as plague) and non-lethal (such as muscle parasites). Most of them can be healed or obtained during the game. Surgeries also play a big part of the game. So installing bionic eyes or peg legs can get pretty common. There are also tons of faction, a whole planet to explore (not that you will do that, but you can do that). Many different weapons, skills, traits and backstories (which determine your colonists). The game is deep. I have to give a tip of my hat to that.+ Your moral choices. Do you want to harvest organs from prisoners to sell them? Or do you want to recruit and save everybody you can? You decide how you answer these questions. And you decide whether you value more life of a prisoner or heart condition of your colonist.+ Different difficulty levels. There are 3 "AI storytellers" (about them later), each with his/her own difficulty levels. So you can decide whether you want raids full of people (making it harder) or base-builder difficulty (just for fun).+ Music and sounds. The music and sounds are amazing. Not perfect, but I really enjoy them. I often listen to OST of the game, personally I like it very much.Neutral points, which can be good for some people and bad for others:+/- Mods. The game supports mods. There are a lot of mods, which add or change the game. They make combat more real, surgeries more fun or even add Cthulhu. However, mods mean instability. And each game update will result in waiting for mods to update. Once, my save got corrupted because of mods. This doesn't happen very often (according to Google), but keep that in mind.+/- Learning curve. The game requires lots of time to play and learn. If you can only spend 1-2 hours a week, this game might simply be bad for you. However, if you are willing to learn the game and willing to play it a lot, you will have lots of fun.+/- Requires creativity. The game is not a game with a plot. YOU make the plot by yourself, dependent on random events by AI storytellers (about them later). If you are not ready to use imagination or just wanna build a big colony without having any attitude towards any specific person...then the game might simply get boring to you.+/- Micromanagement. The game is all about micromanagement. It means that even though colonist do the jobs you told them to do (you can assign each colonist a specific job, dependent on their skills), you will often have to manually say "hunt these animals" or "cut these trees, don't you see, you don't have any left at home". This doesn't change as game progresses. It doesn't become automatic (this is not Factorio), unless you install mods. But this can be fun if you enjoy micromanagement. If you don't, then the game is definitely not for you.And negative points. If you are okay with them, then you definitively should buy the game. Otherwise...depends on you.- "AI storyteller". The game has this description about storytellers: "RimWorld is a story generator. It’s designed to co-author tragic, twisted, and triumphant stories about imprisoned pirates, desperate colonists, starvation and survival. It works by controlling the “random” events that the world throws at you. Every thunderstorm, pirate raid, and traveling salesman is a card dealt into your story by the AI Storyteller. There are several storytellers to choose from. Randy Random does crazy stuff, Cassandra Classic goes for rising tension, and Phoebe Chillax likes to relax." However, there is no story generation. Each storyteller is not an "Artificial Intelligence". Each of the storytellers is basically the set of initial values, which define how random events are generated. Storytellers don't decide that "because there was a raid, neighbour factions sent free stuff with drop-pods". They simply randomly generate raid and then randomly generate drop-pods. Storytellers NEVER say a word and you only remember them when you choose your difficulty. As I said before, if you don't have creativity, you won't get any story in this game. However, if you do, then you will have very fun experience.- RNG (basically randomness of the game). The game is heavily dependent on random events (see AI storyteller). And each action has a random chance of being successful or fail. It leads to those moments, when you scream at your dying colonist, who was killed by a low-skilled raider with a bow, who just got a lucky shot. However, it works both ways. I think the game is way too random at times. As of A16, surgery is very random. "Minor failure" of installing a peg leg can lead to death. This is stupid, and sometimes frustrating. Even though surgery is planned to be changed, as of now, consider that sometimes it might be a bit strange. - Graphics. Yeah, they a bit bad. Looks like prisoner architect, though it is not one. I think that is not a really big dropback, but if you are the graphics-person, then you won't like the graphics.- UI. UI is confusing at times. It is not bad, but requires some clicking to learn. Moreover, some parts of the game can require mods. For example, I had to install "Medical tab", so that my doctors wouldn't use best medicine on scratches. So you can use mods to fix the UI...- Lack of demo. The game lacks demo and it is bad. That is why people are unable to try it before buying. 2 hours are not enough to taste the game fully. So if you are unsure, WATCH gameplay. Definitely do that before buying, if you are really unsure. But if you don't mind RNG, micromanagement and can spend lots of time, then you can easily buy it.As conclusion, the game has "96% positive" on Steam. It doesn't mean that YOU will like the game. There are some problems with it. However, I personally enjoy it a lot. If unsure, ask questions in comments. Thank you!

content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								>Buys game>Starts a new game with the three survivors>First one named Glenn. He was our muscle, so he hauled stuff around and used a pistol>Second one is Dan. He was our sheriff and sharpshooter>Third one was named Min. She was in love with Dan and was our planter and miner.>First day they build house and beds. >Second day we find uranium.>Third day we found a crashed pod with a dying person in it named Gert.>Girt was our slave until the next day when she joined us.>All is good when potatos are harvested and everyone has a party.>We name our settlement New Moscow>Dan purposed to Min and she said yes. >Wedding hall is made in a ruined old granite house.>A wanderer joins us named Lyra. She was useless.>Foggy rain the next day>A wild animal raids us... But what?>It is a rhino!>Dan and Glenn set up defences in the sandbags only armed with a pistol and rife. >Others are hiding>The rhino charges Glenn as he fires pointlessly.>His head was torn off by the horn.>Dan retreats into house leading rhino to where the pet and the hiding people are.>Dan is bloodied while the others (Not including Lyra) Stabbed the rhino to death>Death part was not true.>Another person bloodied. This time it was Min.>Lyra was also bloodied by the tusk into the chest.>Gert quickly grabs the pistol and fires at the rhino as a last ditch attempt to live.>The rhino falls down.>She stabs it to death with a shiv.>A grave is made for Glenn while the others are in critical condition.>Dan recieved a peg leg after they realised he lost one.>Lyra expires next morning. Another hole in the ground. > Battery explodes.>Everyone tries to take out the flames >The hospitol burns down with patients inside.>Dan goes insane and runs away.>Gert dies from a raider attack soon after the fire stopped12/10 Best rhino killing, Peg leg pirate, Widow making game everThe god emperor approves this one.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								NB: Have owned the game since early alpha outside of Steam. Probably close to 700 hours I would estimate.Can't remember the last time I wrote a review, I guess I don't feel the need to do it except in extremis. This is without doubt one of the best value-for-money games I have ever bought. The slow but steady development has left me returning again and again to each release, happily playing it for days or weeks on end. The community is awesome and the mods available are excellent.I'm so happy that the developer gets to see their work hit #1 globally, it's a very fitting and well deserved reward. Here's to RimWorld continuing for many years to come. Now, back to finish removing various body parts before I send these people home.

content:
Posted: March 16
Early Access Review
								A friend suggested this game to me; since paying full price for it I've gotten more than my money's worth out of it.It's basically a fully-skinned (ui) of that ridiculous dwarf fortress game you could never get into because every modded skin you tried was just as horrible as the last.People compare the graphics/mechanics to prison architect but ♥♥♥♥ prison architect, that game's asthetic/plot is just awful (I literally wouldn't, and didnt, pay ~5$ for it, when it was on humble bundle).The game is extremely pause friendly and has never ever crashed on me before (only lag if you use certain worldsize settings). Play at whatever speed you like, the more you micromanage the more efficent your colony will be.The base game has plenty of content, but still leaves some to be desired (like more unique enemies, guns, buildings etc.); from what I see, all of the can be accomplished through mods...still havn't gotten there yet though! I really hope this developer takes hints and integrates much of what mods offer into the game c:I definately wouldn't pass this one up if it looks interesting at-first-glance.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is unequivocally the most I have ever played any game, hands down. I must have 500+ hours playing it and have had the Kickstarter and beyond versions since initial pre-alpha release. The roleplay that you create when you have your characters is just like that feeling you had when you were a kid playing with toys. Each of them had a personality and you fought them and had them get along. It really brings the wonder of just letting fun happen organically right back to me as if I were 5 again.If you like sci-fi, basebuilding, and/or, most clearly inspired, Firefly, then you need to get this game. I promise you you wont be disappointed. the complexity of the game may seem daunting at first but I know that within an hours or two you will have a good hang of how to get around and the fun will just start to flow like water.Edit: formatting and clarity

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8
Early Access Review
								If you want to step up your casual gaming from The Sims series to something more extreme, RimWorld is it. It's as difficult as Dwarf Fortress, but there are easier difficulties (and three different 'storytellers' that control what happens) that you could pretend like you're playing The Sims. Plus, there's no household cap of 8! Anyone that survives, crashing into your colony - or enemies you capture from a raid - you can *convince* them to join your colony and become a part of the family. :)  Once you're comfortable with observing your Sims, I mean, colonists get cozy - bump up the difficulty for hordes of your neighbors, space pirates, and even space alien robots. No one could make fun of you for that. Yes, sure, you can make people into hats.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 18
Early Access Review
								If you enjoy micromanging every moment of your game, this is the challenge you're looking for. RimWorld, or as I like to call it: RimJob. RJ will keep you engaged with a plenty of random events to deal with from whichever AI you pick. From lightining srikes that turn a single flame into a raging inferno, poison clouds that suffocate every living thing for days at a time, to emotional instablities of your colonists. Most days are a new struggle with some rewarding moments thrown in.SQUARETOP:Life in the colony of Squaretop wasn't easy. Stranded on a new planet with a few meals and essentials destined for survival. We had to build walls and build quickly. The initial crew (Vurn, Dacil and Sephicite) survived fires, 3-man raider attacks, and captured many raider prisoners whom after some time were convinced by Vurn to join our cause. After 10 years the Harambe faction became the most coveted in the area, we heavily invested silver into creating nearby allies that we could trade with and call on for help. The poison clouds wiped our crops and killed our animals but still we remained strong. Our stockpile of food encased in Marble walls kept the colony of 9 happy while the natural disasters came and went. It seemed all was well, Joy was reaching new levels, simple meals turned into fine meals. Sweltering heat blistered each year but the A/C kept us cool. Squaretop had it's first gay male couple; Sephicite fell in love with a captured prisoner turned colonist named Ray. He was known throughout as RayJ for how he liked to sing sweet love songs to all the colonists. RayJ was desperately seeking love with any living being in the colony. It didn't matter if you had a peg leg, prosthetic arm, or a brain implant. After multiple rejections RayJ found love with Sephicite in a hopeless place. The colony held a wedding and a party in their honor, everyone attended. Life hummed along and the Squaretop expanded quickly and researched many new technologies. YEAR 15:In year 15, our luck started to turn: Vurn died in a mining accident when a roof collapsed and crushed his body. None of his remains were found. The entire colony was disheartened by our Warden's and best doctor passing. He was a social butterly that no longer graced our marble floors or hospital beds with his presence. During this year a firestorm wiped out the majority of the map but our research in firefoam poppers kept the colony walls safe from a fiery intrusion.While in awe of the firestorm a infestion of bugs manifested itself inside our primary mining node. Several colonists were called on to clear the infestation after preparing for a few days. During the preparation the bugs multiplied in number. The 4 man clearing team was severely wounded and spent 5 days in the med bay recovering after the mission. The team mostly returned to their daily work and was effective even if their movement was a bit slower than before, except for one. Sephicite caught multiple stray friendly fire bullets to the head during the infestation mission and had lost his eyesight. He was unable to navigate around the colony or continue his duty as a Hunter. After much debate it was deterined that he was a useless member of the colony and was euthanized in the 15th year by his lover RayJ. A burial was held in his honor, a sandstone sarcophagus was formed by Dacil as his final resting place. RayJ entered a state of depression and began to experience mental breaks. RayJ had a tendency to be a pyromaniac and began to burn down the colony from the inside out. RayJ successfully burned down the food and medical supplies. The fire was contained and so was RayJ. He was placed in a steel walled room with no door and concrete floors. I determined RayJ will be tortured for what he has done to the remaining 7 colonists. The warm exhaust of a cooling vent pushed the temps to over 80C in his contained cell. RayJ died from heat exhaustion and was buried in a wooden sarcophagus next to his dead lover. There was no ceremony held for RayJ. The colony was desparately trying to replenish food supplies through hunting and trade. RAIDER TEAM ALPHA:That's when the best equipped raider team we have ever seen showed up. It had just turned to the 16th year when raider crew B.A.M.F showed up with mortars and established a permiter of sandbags for defense. They brought survival meals and were ready for a long battle. What once was 9 colonists was now only 6 for defense. Of the 6 remaining Diver was incapable of fighting though he was drafted anyway. He would serve as a human meat shield and if possible would haul the wounded to the hospital. We called our allies for help, they would arrive in 3 days and the colony was drafted and formed up on preparation positions. I determined 3 would attack head on lead by Diver the meat shield and 3 flanking from the east side to take out the mortar operator. Diver was immediately hit with the most accurate shots I've seen in RimJob to date. The five man raider crew landed direct hits and he was the first casualty killed instantly. There would be no rescue for Diver. Dacil lead the flanking team and they sucessfully downed two raiders. The head on meat shield team now lead by Tako the Brawler another former prisoner was badly hurt. He was losing blood quickly and the hospital was far away. They would have to fight and try to survive. Moments later Tako was downed by shotgun fire and his mate Erin attepted to rescue him. Erin made it out of small arms fire range when she caught a direct Mortar round with her face. Tako and Erin died instantly. RIP. Three colonists of Squaretop were remaining and four raiders left. We only needed to down one more raider and it was likely they would retreat. The flanking crew hid behind trees and attempted to take down the raiders from range using assault rifles. The colony aim wasn't true that day and the raiders were operating like the legendary Chris Kyle. I sent Mikey south as a distraction and tried to reposition my crew closer to the sandbags. Mikey caught a mortar, was downed, and began to bleed out from a missing left leg. Dacil's movement was impaired from multiple gun wounds to both legs and torso. The only colonist left capable of moving was Curry. Chef Curry was the colonist cook and he had a recipe for disaster. Chef Curry retreated out of sight when I seen the aid show up from our neighboring ally. I sent Curry back in the fight to bake the raiders from the south while they were attacking the allied force. The 3 allies were ill equipped to handle the 4 heavily armed raiders. Poor quality clubs were no match for the raiders as the allies were also taken down, 2 were killed, one downed and left for dead. Curry couldn't hit the side of a barn during this time and was also downed by assault rifle fire. At this point the remaining raiders had won... My colonists were being captured and taken away. Dacil the last remaining downed colonist remained. Once she died, the colony of Squaretop was no more.THE END:This was my 5th RJ colony and I'd say every single one was a major learning experience. I played without save points (Save only on exit, the True RJ experience) The randomness of my attackers fire during the final raider fight was enough for me to quit the game permanently. I mostly just stared in awe as things went from OK to OH to WOW to WTF. I had several crew that were 13/20 and higher shooters and they couldn't hit anything even when equipped with superior weapons. RNG FTW. This also happened while hunting turkeys at times being unable to shoot them at melee range. Seems a bit ridiculous. I'd still recommend the game to anyone with a lot of patience.

But she's a strong woman and will regrow the colony.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5
Early Access Review
								Yes buy it.It still has very minor issues in the day to day gameplay.  It has a good balance between planning and execution, with random events taking place provided by which storyteller you choose.  I.e. the storyteller (apparently) provides the non-deterministic events in the world, which can range from pirate raids or lunar eclipses to the wildlife going crazy.It seems to play like a D20 game.The Good:- Characters have to sleep each day - which usually means hitting fast forward.  This provides a casual feeling to the game - the game is not rushed.- It might even be the most casual "chill" game I can remember.  You can pause the clock at any moment or revert to an old save.  So even when things are getting heavy you can think through what needs to happen.- The game setting is living in the wild and pulling together a survival plan in the midst of the storyteller generating random events.  It's very easy-going this way -- not like Prison Architect which was too heavy and dark for me.- Grizzly bears seem to just eat berries.  Now you know storyteller will make them go crazy at any moment - so try to figure out a way to deal with them.The Bad:- The price feels high before you buy it.  So it might take longer before many people try this game.  - The game could provide more pointers.  "Just look it up on the Wiki."  I suppose if you're hardcore you will want to figure everything out - but this is the blurry line between gameplay-based enjoyment and arbitrary recipe search-space Easter Egg hunting.- There's no demo.  You can watch youtube videos all day - you'll think this is a Dwarf fortress thing like I did, but it's not, and all the videos don't do the game justice.  A demo would have helped me get over the price hump.As it is this game is easily worth the asking price.  Listen - you have 2 hours to figure it out - if you still want a refund, you'll know after first hour.

								After 75 hours I finally beat the game after 4 attemps!Ok lets try to describe this game for others:The game is a mix between an random generated world, mixed with base building like in Prison Architect, Unique "Characters" that are somekind randomized.I know it really sounds simple - in the core it is - but in my opinion it's hard to master!There are random event that can change everything...Your colony is up and running?Dry Thunderstorm which spreads 4 fires at once over the whole map and all trees start burning and your only have 4 colonists who will die in the flames... Next round i thought about cutting all the trees near my building so the fire can't spread that fast!Srsly I love this game it gave me sooooo much joy! I'll keep this game in my mind.Although the game doesn't really have a real story, but all the random events and encounters telling their own story - despite the fact that the story will develop in you mind!Pro:+ Unique Gameplay+ Good Mix of Genres+ High Replayability+ Random Events*Cons:- Random events*- Sometimes not enough options for certain mechanics*Sometimes those Random Events are unbalanced, therefore it can be a Pro/Con.

content:

Early Access Review
								I don't normally write reviews, but here is one of my stories that just happened:Andrea started this colony on her own with her dog, Mandy. Over time,♥♥♥♥♥♥ Lidia, Calvin, Othello, and Ian join the crew. Now♥♥♥♥♥♥was there from day 3. I tried to get them to hook up, but then Lidia came crashing out of the sky (literally) and won over♥♥♥♥♥♥ That was fine. Now let's talk about Calvin. Calvin was this big guy that joined the colony sometime after Lidia and♥♥♥♥♥♥started sleeping together. Calvin had a thing for Lidia. Lidia didn't care. Andrea, however, was that friend next door/co-worker type; You saw them all the time and talked, but you didn't see them as anything more. Some time went on and Ian joined the group. Ian was Andrea's long lost brother and no one liked him (including me, but that's beside the point).One day Ian goes out hunting and pulls a Robert Baratheon (mauled by a boar). Ian dies and Andrea is devastated. Calvin and Andrea start to talk a bit more here and there. Next thing I know, they are lovers. Before bed on their first night, they vist the grave of Ian. They go to bed and wake up as usual. That's when it happened.Two raiders appear.Now Lidia and♥♥♥♥♥♥don't do♥♥♥♥♥♥(incapable of violence bull♥♥♥♥♥♥. Othello, Calvin, and Andrea run out and take these thugs down. Calvin is attacking one raider while Othello is taken out by the other and being carried away. Andrea runs to save Othello because Calvin is a big guy and is holding his own. Andrea takes out the raider, but it's too late for Othello. She runs back to Calvin to find the raider has killed him. She beats the holy hell out of that raider and heads to the hospital nearly dead herself. While this is all happening, our only prisoner has gone berserk and breaks out of prison. The prisoner attacks Andrea's dog, Mandy, and beats her to death.Andrea sleeps in the hospital for a whole day and wakes up on the brink of a meltdown.♥♥♥♥♥♥and Lidia try to help with the healing and cleaning, but Andrea winds up wandering off into the forest because of all the grief. I wanted to follow right along side her.Moral of this story: do not become attached. I was warned and learned the hard way. This game is amazing. Buy it already. I read many of these reviews for the stories and was so glad when I finally created some of my own. I can't wait to see what else they do with this game.5/7

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is absolutely ridiculous and ridiculously hard.  I love it.The commands are largely simple, but the interactions and complexity are huge-- reminiscent of NetHack, Dwarf Fortress, or the like, but much more approachable.  The game is HARD.  Progress is hugely satisfying, but defeat is frequent (and often hilarious).I recommend getting the "Prepare Carefully" mod, and that's it.  Even WITH "Prepare Carefully", the game is really hard, but it's a thoroughly enjoyable challenge.The "Narrator AI" gimmick is a neat approach, and it works really well.  It's most fun to use the slacky relaxed settings until you have a big♥♥♥♥♥colony, then switch it over to something harder.  Oh, the chaos and mayhem.The backstory engine is surprising, too!  Your colonists will surprise you, and will actually be interesting.  Well, except for the graphics, but you get used to that pretty quick.Great work, guys!  Keep bolting on!PS:  Oh, yes-- if you ever feel your colony has become invincible:1. Buy 250 fertilized chicken eggs.2. Wait.3. Laugh at little chicks everywhere.4. Several minutes of business as usual.5. Starve.6. Realize that chickens need to eat-- and they did.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								So everything was lovely in "Melhadfs World", crops were growing indoors under a sun lamp safely, everyone had a bedroom, the solar power surplus was enough to get through a winter night without difficulty. Even Raids were easily defeated.But then a storm came, greater than anything else. Lightning tore the sky, and my colonists slept.  Nothing could disturb the sleep of the hard working survivors. They had earned it.Over the horizon a predawn light grew, a flicker at first in the distance, then another on the opposite horizon and a third to the south. The light grew brighter, a blaze slowly enveloping the screen. the colonists awoke to fire ripping through the roof, all but one immeditately started to put out the blaze.  The other one, well she did the most british thing possible, she prepared a meal and cup of tea for the firefighters.But the blaze was too out of control, slowly people succumbed to the effects of the fire, passing out and being consumed in the blaze. While the lone tea maker wondered what had happened. She eventually went looking for them, upon seeing their corpses she ran into the blaze to save her lover... but it was not to be and she died just out of arms reach of him.The fire consumed everything, leaving nothing but 8 burnt bodies.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have been playing this game now for some time, and backed it on Kickstarter in 2013.  Since this time the game has continued to grow and develop at a great pace.  This review is based on Alpha 14, the last version before Steam release.  I estimate that I have approximately 200 hours of play.The setting for this game is a group of people in a sci-fi frontier backdrop (Firefly) trying to survive.  Rimworld is described as a "Sci-fi Colony Sim" by the creators, whilst accurate it is a rather dull description of what is a very fun and exciting game.  This game has the depth of Dwarf Fortress with the aesthetics and visual style of Prison Architect.  Throw in a great 'western' (as in cowboy) soundtrack and you have something pretty special.  This is a niche game, it is not for people who prefer form over function, but after watching the trailer you will know if that is you or not.This game is hard on its default / average settings.  Your colonists will get sick and die, you will run out of food, wildlife and raiders will attack, colonists will freeze to death or go mad, and natural phenomenon will thwart best laid plans.  Luckily, the amount of customisation available is huge.  You really can tweak most options in the game, by changing your starting climates, picking your storyteller type and difficulty and selecting custom rules.  You can select a random group of survivors or re-roll them as many times as you like.  Options that are not changeable in game are often mod-able.  The Ludeon Studios forum has hundreds of mods available, although many will likely require updating to be compatible with the Steam release.  I would like to thank the creator of “EdB Prepare Carefully” for making a mod that I find it hard to play the game without.The sandbox in this game is rather large.  If you wish to build a small cannibalistic tribe (yes, you really can) that live in wooden huts in a jungle, you can.  If you want to build into a mountainside for the true Dwarf Fortress feel, you can.  Want to tame animals to attack hostile entities or help with hauling, guess what, you can.The story progresses nicely at a pace determined by the storyteller options you selected at the start.  A typical playthrough will have you rushing at the start to get shelter, and food.  As you expand and more colonists join you will look towards researching new technology, and upgrading security measures.  After a source of electricity is constructed, you can really start to grow.  All the while you will have a number of challenges, some brutal, some comical.  I recall one raid that followed after a solar flareMy only criticism of the game is that at the time of writing this, you cannot visit other colonies on the world map to raid or trade with them.  I would not be surprised however if this changes in the future.EDIT: Regarding the only criticism above, it has now been added!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27
Early Access Review
								Surprisingly good - this is the best way of describing RimWorld.  The last time I played an indie game with as much potential for replayability was FTL.  If you liked FTL, I'll take a leap here and say you will like RimWorld.  Very different in its concept, but similar in it's addictiveness and replayability which for me is really important.Each time you start a new colony the experience is slightly different.  Obviously there are similarities between games which have had me sighing a little when a colony goes wrong and I have start a new one, but on a whole its quite fresh each time a new game is started.  You build a base from scratch and collect resources, but the little people you start with have real vices and personalities, some are hard workers, some lazy, some hate each other, some spawn new little people if they get together!  Pets can be trained if you have a animal friendly little person too, and they can help fight off attackers or fetch resources.  This can sound gimmicky and a little micro-management heavy, and I was a little sceptical when I read about the AI story teller, but actually it really does work and is fun and balanced.If you're like me and prefer a permadeath game RimWorld comes with that option, and its great, knowing if something goes wrong (and it often does) you just have to keep going till your team recover or all is lost, and that makes the experience deeper, because sometimes you start to feel the journey with your characters, particularly if some get killed or maimed.  I actually got properly sad once when one character died and then his pet dog died defending him afterwards, I ended that game, and that was the end of that story.  The beauty is, you can then start again with new people and have another 'largely' unique adventure.Give it a go, it’s worth it just for the experience, it’s quite a unique game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 12
Early Access Review
								Well here is the story of my most recent colony:  A sea ice oneLanded with three colonists. Mason,  Farrukh, and JaydenJayden was my crack shot great against raidersMason was a great researcher and constructer Farrukh grew food and cookedI get a survival shelter up, got power and a heater get up a research bench even individual bedrooms for my people.  An electric stove.On day 6 I recieve an alert "Manhunter Pack".  It is only three Muffalo I thought I could handle it.To say the least we had to leave behind Mason's foot and Jayden's eye. I didn't even have enough resources to build a butcher table. 3 raids later I still have my colonists and then I get the alert "Siege"  I grab my sniper rifles and head out. Half of my base is destroyed before hep arives including my power so hello "slept in the cold".  By now I am worried abot my numbers.  So accept the person who causes my demise.He was Table a young man a great colonist by my standards.  But the raid that comes is 10 pirates with 4 personal shields.  I grab my guns and hope for the best. I do ok utill the person with the doomsday launcher comes The only one who remains is Mason who is also, inconvienintly my Brawler. He dies in the next raidBut the game decides to troll me and gives me another colonist so I pack my bags with all my food and leave for the tundra.  After a fight with a hungry fox and an infection the game over screen popped upAfter playing 1,500 hours of this game I can easily give it 100/10 and say it is my favorite game.  And it is still in development!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								I really like this game.This game is one of those rare games where you actually really care about your colonists. I've been playing with one colony for about 12 hours now and we've been through a lot. I started my colony with one 19 year old man crash landing onto a planet with his pet dog Scarlet. Now initially, I had no idea how to play, but I did figure it out after a bit. The man named "Bossman" almost died to raiders within 3 days of landing. He got stabbed in the torso and lost his left lung. I initially thought that this would be it, but he recovered from his wounds, he still lost his lung though. Now a couple of colonists named Dally and Lambertus joined and we became good friends. The colony was starting to grow and then we got raided. 3 raiders came in but we took care of them by killing 2 and wounding 1. We captured the Captain named Goki. We convinced him to join our colony and we helped him recover from his wounds, he made a full recovery. Now there was 4. A pod crash landed in our area and 70 year old man named Michael "Chicken" Carlson was wounded from the crash. Initially I didn't want to bother saving him as that was another mouth to feed and he wasn't useful considering he refused to do labour. But I saw that he had a high art skill so I bandaged him up and he joined our colony. Now there were 5. The colony was doing good and a lot of food got harvested, until a woman named Gitta was asking for help. She was being chased by raiders and needed our assistance, so we answered her call. We dealt with the raiders chasing her and she joined our colony. Now there's 6. Dally and Gitta became boyfriend and girlfriend and Dally proposed marraige to Gitta, which she accepted. Bossman is now the doctor, Dally is the cook and constructor, Lambertus is a miner and hauler, Chicken is a sculpter, Gitta is a grower, animal handler and warden and itini is a soldier and hunter. Bossman got surgery from Dally to add a new lung that I bought earlier. Things were looking great until Lambertus, Dally, and Chicken got the flu. That's basically where I am right now, half of my colonists are bed ridden and Bossman is tending to them all and trying to make them feel better. We are having issues with food now and it's almost winter. I'm really hoping we can make it one more year, I have faith for these little people.Definately one of my favourite games this year and for an early access title, It's jam packed with content and has few bugs. If you want a game that makes you emotional and gives you a sense of progression, then this is it.I rate this game a 9/10 in it's current state.(There may be spelling mistakes, it's late and I was tired when I wrote this.)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								So everything was lovely in "Melhadfs World", crops were growing indoors under a sun lamp safely, everyone had a bedroom, the solar power surplus was enough to get through a winter night without difficulty. Even Raids were easily defeated.But then a storm came, greater than anything else. Lightning tore the sky, and my colonists slept.  Nothing could disturb the sleep of the hard working survivors. They had earned it.Over the horizon a predawn light grew, a flicker at first in the distance, then another on the opposite horizon and a third to the south. The light grew brighter, a blaze slowly enveloping the screen. the colonists awoke to fire ripping through the roof, all but one immeditately started to put out the blaze.  The other one, well she did the most british thing possible, she prepared a meal and cup of tea for the firefighters.But the blaze was too out of control, slowly people succumbed to the effects of the fire, passing out and being consumed in the blaze. While the lone tea maker wondered what had happened. She eventually went looking for them, upon seeing their corpses she ran into the blaze to save her lover... but it was not to be and she died just out of arms reach of him.The fire consumed everything, leaving nothing but 8 burnt bodies.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								RimWorld is a game that is a strategy game at it's core, and one with a solid amount of depth, especially with its mod capabilities. The game has a lot of options and considerations, and can be as hard, or as easy, as you want it to be. Yet what always brings me back to the game is the stories the game creates. With a little imagination, you can take the characters you're given, the setting, and the events that occur and weave an epic story that will leave your friends stunned and interested to know just what game you were playing. I love RimWorld because it lets my imagination run wild, and lets me be strategic and a builder. It's a  game that's hard to learn, but has a near limitless amount of potential and fun to be experienced. The only complaint I have about the game is that every time I start it up, hours pass before I can put it down again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								I almost never write reviews, despite having hundreds of hours in many games on Steam. Yet I feel that I must write a review for RimWorld. RimWorld is nothing like you think it will be, period. It is an infinite canvas of stories, experiences, horros, trauma, victories, and more. I have many passions in life and yet I have been craving RimWorld non stop for the last few weeks, I have yet to burn myself out from it. This game is the perfect mixture of "society simulatory" and survival game. I love survival games and I've been looking for one like RimWorld for ages. It's far more intimate and content rich than Dwarf Fortress and the community behind the workshop for this game is out of this world good. And best of all the lead dev is super involved in the community, incredibly reasonable, adaptable, and industrious as hell. The active development of this game is incredibly exciting. It's just insane to me that a game in its Alpha stage could be better and more fleshed out than more than half of the games still in Beta/Early Access on Steam. I deeply apologize for pirating the game for the first few days I played this. Once it became apparent to me that nothing could possibly entertain me more than this game, I immediately bought it on Steam.This game is easily worth more than $30 so the game is worth more than every penny. Now I will return to my Lovecraftian horror story as I watch my colonists get eaten alive by crazed bears and angry cannibals.
